Birth plan. http://www.marchofdimes.org/materials/birth-plan.pdf [Accessed October 2016]MedlinePlus (ADAM). 2016. What to include in your birth plan? https://medlineplus.gov/ency/patientinstructions/000567.htm [Accessed October 2016]Nemours Foundation. 2015. Birth plans. http://kidshealth.org/en/parents/birth-plans.html [Accessed October 2016]OWH. 2010. Labor and birth. U.S. Office on Womens Health. http://www.womenshealth.gov/pregnancy/childbirth-beyond/labor-birth.html [Accessed October 2016]

column1: Saving for college: 529 plans
column3: What is a 529 college savings plan?A 529 college savings plan is a type of investment account that allows you to set aside money for your child's education and let it grow tax-free. The federal government won't tax your money when you take it out of the account, as long as it's used for higher education.Any family can contribute to a 529 account regardless of income, and there's a lifetime maximum contribution (the amount varies from state to state, ranging from $235,000 to $511,000). The best part: You can often start an account with as little as $25.You can use the money in a 529 plan at any accredited college or university in the country public or private, graduate or undergraduate. And it can be used for tuition, fees, room and board, books, supplies, and equipment.All 529 plans are administered by individual states, but if you live in New Jersey, for instance, that doesn't mean you have to invest in the New Jersey plan.You can choose any state plan that meets your needs. If you're not a resident, however, you may face higher commission rates and more limited investment options. And if you choose your own state's plan, you may enjoy state tax benefits.Advantages of a 529 college savings plan529 plans offer huge tax breaksYour money grows tax-free for as long as you keep it in the program. When you take the money out for educational purposes, you won't pay federal taxes on any part of it not on the principal or the earnings. Some states, such as South Dakota, will tax the earnings when you withdraw them, but most won't.For details on current state tax policies, see Saving for College's comparison chart of 529 plans.The money you put in a 529 account is considered a gift and, as such, qualifies for the annual $14,000 gift tax exclusion. That is, you can contribute up to $14,000 annually without incurring any gift tax. According to the gift tax law, you can contribute five years' worth of "gifts" in one year and not incur any gift tax as long as you don't contribute anything for the next four years.So if you had the money available now, for instance, you could contribute up to $70,000 this year ($140,000 if you're married) and let the interest on that money grow and grow. It's also a great way for grandparents to move money out of their estate quickly without incurring taxes.Keep in mind, however, that if you exceed the gift tax contribution limit in a given year, the excess money will be taxed at a rate of 20 to 50 percent, depending on how much you give. If you're considering this option, check with a financial advisor or tax professional first.Note: If you open a 529 account for yourself which is an option, if you plan to go back to school the gift limitations don't apply. That's because money you give to yourself isn't a gift as defined under our tax laws.You stay in control of the moneyWith a 529 plan, you decide when and how much money to withdraw from the account. Compare this to a custodial account, with which your child takes control of the money at the age of majority (which ranges from 18 to 21, depending on state law) and can use it for whatever he chooses.529 plans are very flexibleYou can open accounts for any number of people, regardless of age and regardless of their relationship to you. Some possibilities: Open one for each of your kids, or even for yourself, if you're thinking of going back to school. Grandparents can open accounts for any or all of their grandchildren. A friend or godparent can open one for your child.You can have each child's 529 in a different state if you want to diversify your portfolio. You can even open more than one account per child if you think your child's education expenses might exceed your contribution limit maybe he's on the joint M.D., J.D., MBA track. If your child decides not to go to school or doesn't use the full amount in the account, you can roll the funds over to someone else.Disadvantages of a 529 savings planYour investment options are limited to what's offered by the stateIn a state with three plans, for example, you may choose to put your money into a fund that's made up of all equity mutual funds, such as blue chip stocks and international stocks; a fund of all fixed income securities, such as the U.S. Bond Index fund and a money market account; or a fund of some combination of stocks and securities, depending on how much stock you'd like to hold. You can't, however, decide which blue chip stocks you might like to hold or decide which money market fund to invest in.Although some people may dislike this lack of freedom, many state plans are surprisingly strategic. For example, most states offer an opportunity to automatically alter the mix of stocks and bonds in your investment portfolio as your child approaches college age. When your child is younger, the portfolio is composed of more aggressive stocks, and every quarter the mix in the portfolio becomes more conservative until it's mostly composed of bonds.If you're the type of person who wants more control of your investments, you should consider a Coverdell account as well.If you don't use the money for school, you'll pay heavy penaltiesIf you take money out of a 529 plan for other than educational purposes, you'll be assessed a 10 percent penalty on the earnings, plus you'll have to pay federal taxes on the earnings. To top it off, some states slap on an additional 10 percent penalty for early withdrawal.How will a 529 plan affect my child's financial aid eligibility?The good news is that any money in a 529 account is considered an asset of the parents (or grandparents, or godparents  whoever opened the account), and not of the child. That means your child's eligibility for need-based financial aid will be less affected by a 529 plan than by any other type of asset or savings account. Most other college savings vehicles are considered the child's asset, and this weighs heavily against need-based financial aid eligibility.What's more, 529 plans generally have no effect on merit-based scholarships, so encourage your child to apply for as many as possible. Even in a best-case scenario in which your academic or athletic superstar qualifies for a full-tuition scholarship you'll have no worries about your 529 account. Any extra money you contributed that you don't need because your child received a merit-based scholarship goes back to you, penalty- and tax-free (although earnings may be taxed). Of course, these savings may also be used for education-related expenses.How do I choose a 529 plan?Since nearly every state now operates a 529 college savings plan and many have multiple investment options, choosing where to put your dollars can be daunting. To start getting a feel for what's out there, visit these websites that allow you to access each state's plans and provide a number of tools to help you figure out which plan is best for you.Savingforcollege.comCollege Savings Plans NetworkAs you evaluate each plan, keep the following in mind:Check your own state first. Many let you deduct part of your contributions from your state tax bill, which can save you a lot of money if you live in a state with high taxes.Analyze the investment returns. You can get investment return information from Savingforcollege.com or by calling the plan directly.Find out who runs the plan. Look for a fund group with a solid track record and a good lineup of funds. You can get more information on individual funds from Morningstar, an independent investment research firm in Chicago.Read the fine print and watch out for penalties and restrictions. Some 529 plans impose heavy penalties for withdrawing the money in the first three years. Some plans have age restrictions for instance, they require your child to be younger than 15 to open an account.Find out what the annual maintenance fees and sales commissions are on the plans you're considering. High fees could wipe out your earnings for the year. The prospectus for the account will contain this information.A word about the stock marketLike most savings plans that invest in the stock market, 529 plans are vulnerable to market fluctuations especially plans composed of growth-oriented mutual funds (funds with the riskiest stock holdings).Even the most recommended 529 plans have losses in a bear market. In fact, near the end of 2008, the stocks in 529 portfolios typically lost 40 percent of their value.If you're concerned about losing money in the stock market in the short run, consider investing all your 529 money in a conservative investment fund. Most states offer money market funds or government bond funds that are low-risk investments with typically low returns. If you become more optimistic about the stock market, you can change your investment choices, but most plans allow this only once a year.How do I set up a 529 plan?You can enroll online at either Savingforcollege.com or College Savings Plans Network. Or, if you're feeling overwhelmed by the amount of information available on 529 plans and having trouble settling on the right one for you, consider using a broker. Every major brokerage firm can set up an account for you, though not all brokers offer all 529 plans.If you go the broker route, ask about commissions. They can be high and, in some cases, even wipe out your earnings for the first year. Sales commissions for some state plans are as high as 5.75 percent.A family that invested $6,000 in a 529 plan with a 5.75 percent sales commission would pay $345 in sales charges. With a lower, more typical 3.5 percent sales charge, the family would pay only $210.Still, the service provided could be worth it to you. If the mountain of data on 529s is keeping you from opening an account, an investment of $200 to get started could pay for itself in no time.Show sources Hide sources http://www.savingforcollege.com/articles/heres-how-much-can-you-contribute-to-a-529-plan-in-2016-983

column1: Baby shower planning and etiquette
column3: Who should host the baby shower?It used to be considered bad manners for a family member to throw a shower because it might seem like you're asking for gifts. But these days, just about anything goes. Any relative, close friend, or close co-worker should feel perfectly okay about planning a baby shower.When should the baby shower be held?Most baby showers happen shortly before the baby is born, and a shower makes for a welcome diversion especially toward the end of pregnancy.When setting a date for the party, first consult the parents-to-be. It would be disappointing to plan a party and send out invitations, only to find out that the most important people have a schedule conflict. You also may have to accommodate the travel plans of grandparents, for example, even if they aren't the guests of honor.If you decide to throw a shower after the baby is born, that's fine too. And with a baby as the centerpiece, you'll have a surefire icebreaker and conversation topic.Who should be invited to the baby shower?If you're hosting the shower for a close friend, you may have some ideas about the guest list already. It's best to consult with the guest (or guests) of honor before finalizing your list, though. That way, you won't accidentally leave out someone important  or invite someone they would rather not include.If the parents-to-be have close friends and family who live far away and can't make it to the shower, consider setting up a time during the event when they can be included through FaceTime or Skype. Make sure they get an invitation with all the details! What about hosting a shower for the expectant momanddad?Although many baby showers still follow the "women only" tradition, baby showers for both women and menare also popular. Some dads even have their own baby shower. It all depends on what sort of gathering the expectant mom or parents prefer.Is it okay to throw a baby shower for a second child?Showers for a second or subsequent baby have become more common and are considered appropriate. Parents whose children have a large age gap may be especially appreciative. There's always reason to celebrate a new baby, whether it's a large or small affair.For parents who prefer a smaller event the next time around, consider throwing a "baby sprinkle," which is a scaled-down version of a full shower. For example, the gathering could be an afternoon picnic or a simple pancake breakfast, with or without games. There may be only a small registry or no registry at all.Is a surprise baby shower a good idea?Think long and hard before choosing to throw a surprise party. If your guest of honor doesn't like surprises or was really hoping for a specific type of event, you could put her in an awkward position. On the other hand, if you let the future parents in on the arrangements, you can be confident that they'll be pleased with the outcome.What kind of invitations should I send?You can send invitations by mail or email, or by scheduling an event on social media.In addition to all the basic information (who, what, where, when, and RSVP instructions), it never hurts to let people know thethemeof the shower if there is one. If the expectant parents are registered anywhere for baby gear, it's fine to mention that too. (Or you can give guests the registry information when they RSVP.)When should I send the invitations?Send invitations early enough to give the guests four to six weeks' notice: That way everyone has enough time to put the shower on their calendar and shop for the perfectgift. What should we do at the baby shower?Keep your guest of honor's preferences in mind when it comes to activities. Some moms- and dads-to-be dislike shower games and would rather spend time socializing with guests. Asking about these kinds of things before you start planning ensures that the shower will be fun for everyone.There are many things to consider:You may want to select athemeto tie everything together. It's certainly not necessary, but it can help you make decisions about elements of the party, and it's often fun for guests.Plan to serve some type offood and refreshment, depending on the time of day, your budget, and how fancy (or informal) the shower will be.Some people like to playfun or silly baby shower games, but there are plenty of other festive activitiesto keep guests entertained.It's customary to givefavorsto everyone who attends the baby shower. Or you can offer prizes to the guests who win games instead.Aside from socializing and honoring the parents-to-be, the main event at a baby shower is often opening the gifts. If there's no registry and guests need help figuring out what to bring, have them check our list oftop baby shower giftsand our roundup ofreaders' favorite baby shower gifts.Show sources Hide sources The Emily Post Institute. Undated. Top baby shower etiquette questions. http://emilypost.com/advice/top-baby-shower-etiquette-questions [Accessed March 2016]Pinterest. Undated. Men's baby showers. https://www.pinterest.com/explore/men's-baby-showers [Accessed March 2016]

How can we have a pleasant family meal with a 2-year-old?
Dinnertime is a nightmare at our house. How can we have a pleasant family meal?
How to avoid making meals a power struggle (ages 2 to 4)
column3: How can I avoid arguing with my child over food at every meal?For many families, sitting down together for a meal often means fighting over food  what's on the menu, who's eating (or not eating) what and how much. But who wants that night after night?To avoid squabbles at supper, try not to talk about food at the table and simply serve the meal without comment. Make meals a stress-free time when you talk together about pleasant things.Of course, if your child is a picky eater, holding your tongue can require a lot of restraint. But your child will benefit in the long run if you don't harp on his eating habits throughout the meal.Nutritionists say it's your job to decide what, when, and where to eat, and it's your child's job to figure out the rest. Provide your child with reasonable, healthy food choices, but dont force him to eat. As difficult as it may be, its important to give your child some control  and you may be surprised to learn how good children can be at self-regulation when it comes to food."It's your child's decision whether or not to eat, what to eat from what is being offered, and how much of it," says Nancy Hudson, a registered dietitian at the University of California at Davis.What if my child refuses to eat what I serve?Your mom may have rewarded you with a bowl of ice cream for cleaning your plate, but that just demonstrated that veggies were the punishment and dessert was the reward.Instead, try this approach: Serve at least one food you know your kid likes, don't discuss eating habits, and clear the table when the meal is over  even if your child doesn't eat all his food. Its okay if hes still hungry after dinner.Dont become a short-order cook, preparing special meals just to appease your child. And don't give snacks close to mealtime  your child is more likely to eat if hes hungry.If your child turns up his nose at a new food, don't be afraid to serve it again. Try cooking it a different way or serving it raw. Kids often need to be exposed to a new food several times before they learn to like it. Give it time and don't force it.If he wants dessert, give it to him without much fanfare, but consider serving fruit instead of a sugary treat. Treating dessert as a reward for finishing his vegetables risks teaching him that vegetables arent enjoyable. Offering more nutritious desserts along with occasional treats like ice cream encourages healthy habits.Its also important to be a good role model. If your child sees you enjoying your meals, hes more likely to enjoy his as well.How can I tell if my child is eating well enough?Remember that your child is the one in control of what he puts into his body. Deciding for your child when he's hungry or when he's had enough to eat ultimately does him a disservice: "He won't learn to recognize when he's hungry and when he's done, and you're setting him up for eating problems later, such as obesity, overeating, or controlling food," says Hudson."Children are amazingly good at self-regulation. They may eat almost nothing one day, and then the next day they eat a ton of food," Hudson says.If you watch what your child eats over the course of a week or a month, you'll see that he does a pretty good job of getting what he needs from different food groups (as long as you offer a variety). So, pull up a chair, relax, and try to enjoy your meal. If you do, your child will, too.For more help, check out our articles on coping with picky eaters.

column1: Does your family watch TV during meals?
Saving for college: Prepaid tuition plans
column3: What is a prepaid tuition plan?Prepaid tuition plans are investment accounts that allow you to pay for your child's future college tuition (or a portion of it) at today's prices. If you have enough money now, you could pay for a complete four-year degree that your child won't use for another 18 years. Or, if your budget's more modest, you can prepay a portion of your child's college expenses.Some plans allow you to purchase individual tuition credits. Others let you buy a semester's or year's worth of tuition. Prepaid tuition plans are actually a variation on the popular 529 college savings plans, but they're virtually risk-free. For starters, you can't lose any of the money you invest in them.Prepaid tuition plans are administered by individual states, and most can only be redeemed at public colleges and universities in that state. In many cases, you or the student beneficiary of the account must also live in that state. About 19 states currently offer prepaid plans.Here's an example of how a prepaid account works: Say a state university requires about 400 tuition credits for a four-year bachelor's degree and the equivalent of another 400 credits for room and board, and each credit costs $78. That means that if you buy a package covering tuition, plus room and board today, you'll pay $62,400.It's a hefty tab, but compare it to the $128,000 bill you'd be paying in 15 years, when those credits will likely cost $160 each, according to current projections. You're looking at a savings of $65,600! From an investment perspective, that's a 4.9 percent rate of return  not great, compared with the enormous gains stock market investors enjoyed in the late '90s, but pretty darn good for an investment with no risks.Prepaid tuition plans have been around for about 20 years, but they've become more flexible in recent years. Many states are now paying minimal interest on prepaid contracts, which guarantees a return on your investment even if tuition rates don't go up. What if my child doesn't want to go to school in our home state or she gets into Princeton?Many state plans have made it easier to transfer the money in your account to private schools or public universities in other states if your child decides not to attend college in your home state. But keep in mind that the amount of money you invested for an in-state school probably won't cover tuition at a private or out-of-state school.In some states, if you cancel the prepaid contract, there's no penalty  just a fee of about $50 to $150. Other states assess a 10 percent penalty on earnings.To find out more about the rules for your state's plan, visit Mapping Your Future.Your prepaid options aren't limited to public universities. About 250 private schools have come together to form their own prepaid tuition plan called the Independent 529 Plan, which began in 2003. The tuition plan consortium includes Princeton, Stanford, MIT, Emory, Loyola, Notre Dame, Baylor, Amherst, and many other top-notch universities.If you purchase this plan, your child can use the tuition credits at any participating school. If your child decides not to go to one of these schools, the plan will give you a full refund with interest. This modest interest isn't taxed as long as you spend the money on higher education.For more information, check the FinAid.website.Advantages of a prepaid tuition planPrepaid tuition plans are a virtually risk-free way to pay for collegeIf you're worried about the stock market, a prepaid plan allows you to avoid market uncertainty. There's no way you can lose the money in your prepaid account. If you buy a year's worth of college today, you get a year's worth when you redeem the account.This is particularly appealing if you have a child who'll be attending college in the next four to five years. In that short time frame, you could experience zero growth in a stock market investment or even lose some money. With college tuitions rising fast (between 2006 and '07, tuition and fees rose 6.3 percent at four-year public colleges and 5.9 percent at four-year private colleges, according to the nonprofit College Board), paying for your child's schooling today almost guarantees substantial savings.Some prepaid tuition plans offer tax benefitsSome states also offer a state tax break for investing in a prepaid tuition plan. Plans based on bond funds may also offer federal tax benefits.Prepaid tuition plans don't affect financial aid eligibilityYour distributions to a prepaid tuition plan no longer affect your child's financial aid eligibility, thanks to the Higher Education Reconciliation Act of 2005. Just like a 529 college savings plan, prepaid tuition is treated as an asset of the owner  the parents. (Previously, the plan's value counted as a child's asset, reducing aid eligibility dollar for dollar.) That means these plans are now a good option for lower-income as well as middle-income families who may not have qualified for aid. Students with prepaid tuition plans are still eligible for merit scholarships that can help pay other school expenses Disadvantages of a prepaid tuition planYour child's college choices are limitedMost prepaid plans are designed for state residents for use at public colleges and universities within that state. Many do have cancellation or transfer policies, but the money you invest in the plan won't go as far at a private or out-of-state school because tuitions at those institutions are typically much higher than in-state universities.Prepaid accounts may limit your investment growth potentialAs with most low-risk investments, prepaid tuition plans have limited growth potential  most plans generally offer basic interest in the 4 to 5 percent range per year. If the stock market should rally and all your money is tied up in a prepaid tuition account, you'll miss out on potential investment income.Where can I find out more about prepaid tuition plans?The nonprofit Tuition Plan Consortium provides a list of private colleges that participate in the Independent 529 Plan.Savingforcollege.com offers lists of state prepaid tuition plans, as well as details about each state's plan. Click on Prepaid Contract and Prepaid Unit/Guaranteed Savings to see them.

column1: How to plan a great Halloween party
column3: With just a few tricks, you can treat your kids and their friends to a party they won't soon forget. Here are tips for creating a perfectly spooky setting, a menu of ghastly goodies, and plenty of mischievous merriment.Diabolical decorationsGauze ghostsWhether you use these mini apparitions as part of a table setting or line them up on a windowsill or countertop, they're guaranteed to get young party guests in the Halloween spirit. Make enough for everyone to take one home when the party's over.You'll need:A cookie sheetWax paperAluminum foil, cut into 6-by-8-inch rectanglesLiquid glue (such as Elmer's)Gauze, cut into 4-by-4-inch squares (or use precut 2-inch-square gauze bandages, unfolded)Line the cookie sheet with wax paper. Next, make forms for your mini-ghosts by crumpling the aluminum foil into conical, ghost-like shapes, with a round head and a flaring skirt. Space the forms evenly on the wax paper. In a bowl, mix together 1/2 cup of glue and 1/2 cup of water. One at a time, dip the pieces of gauze into the glue solution, then squeeze out most of the liquid and drape the gauze over a foil form, covering it completely. Let the ghosts air dry completely (two to four hours), then gently remove the foil forms from underneath the gauze. Using a black permanent marker, draw on circular eyes and open mouths.Dangling spidersWhen it comes to these decorative arachnids, the more the scarier! But have no fear  they're a cinch to make. And their lightweight balloon bodies make them ideal for hanging overhead. Just be sure to assemble them on the day of the party or the night before so the balloons don't have time to deflate.You'll need: 10-inch balloons (black is ideal, but any dark color will do)Black pipe cleanersStringFor each spider, inflate a balloon and tie it closed. Hold the balloon on its side  the inflated part will form the body, while the knot will be the head. For the legs, hold four black pipe cleaners in a bunch and, treating them as one, wrap the middle of the pipe cleaners tightly around the balloon neck, forming eight legs (four on each side). Next, separate the pipe cleaner ends and make two bends in each to create a knee joint and a foot. Lastly, tie a long piece of string around the knot where the legs are attached, and the spider's ready to hang. Frightening (but fantastic) foodBat ear chips and green slime dipPartygoers will go batty over this "ear-ie" appetizer: blue corn tortilla chips served with creamy guacamole. Don't forget to provide a serving spoon so kids can transfer helpings of "green slime" to their own plates before dipping in.More green slimeYou can't beat the simplicity of this delightfully goopy Halloween concoction. In a blender, mix together a few drops of green food coloring and a jarful of applesauce until super smooth and just the right shade of slime. Serve with graham crackers for dipping.Mummy munchiesMum's the word when it comes to the inspiration for this tasty finger food. Slice flour tortillas into 1/2-inch-wide strips. Then cut hot dogs into quarters lengthwise so they form long, thin strips. Wrap each hot dog piece in a tortilla strip, mummy-style, moistening the end of the strip with a drop of water to make it stick. Arrange the mummy munchies end-side-down on a nonstick cookie sheet and bake them at 425 degrees for five to seven minutes, until the edges of the tortilla strips are just starting to crisp. Allow the munchies to cool for a few minutes before serving, then set them out with a cup of "blood" (a.k.a. ketchup) for dipping.Jack-o'-lantern sandwichesYour little monsters will find these sweet-faced lanterns irresistible. Using a round cookie cutter, cut out circles from slices of white bread. Spread the cutouts with apricot or peach preserves, then place the "pumpkins" on individual plates. For stems, cut the leftover bread crusts into 1-inch lengths and place one at the top of each pumpkin. Use raisins or currants to give the orange globes eyes and grins. For a savory sandwich variation, cut slices of American cheese into small triangles and arrange them atop the bread circles to resemble a jack-o'-lantern's eyes, nose, and mouth.Eyeball cupcakesThese easy-to-make cupcakes will be gone in the wink of an eye. Simply spread a batch of cupcakes with white frosting. To create a colorful iris, gently press a Life Savers Gummie into the frosting in the center of each cupcake. Then, place a chocolate chip "pupil," tip down, in the middle of the Gummie. As a finishing touch, use red decorator's gel to add squiggly lines for a bloodshot look.Marshmallow goblinsSoft and sweet, these tempting little ghosts are known to do quick disappearing acts. To whip up a batch, cover a flat surface with wax paper. Dust the paper with confectioner's sugar. One at a time, place a marshmallow on the sugared paper and cover it with another piece of wax paper. Use a rolling pin to flatten the marshmallow into a thin, irregular ghost shape. Remove the ghost from the paper and press two mini-chocolate chips, tips down, into the marshmallow to create eyes. Serve on a platter.Witch's brewKids will get a kick out of watching this colorful concoction foam and bubble into a tasty thirst quencher. Pour equal amounts of orange juice and ginger ale into a punch bowl "cauldron." Then drop generous scoops of lime sherbet into tall plastic tumblers and pour a ladle full of brew over each one. Serve at once. Ghoulish gamesMusical pumpkinsThis ramble through a paper pumpkin patch  a noncompetitive variation on musical chairs  is a great way to kick off the party activities. To set it up, cut out large pumpkin circles from orange poster board or construction paper; you'll need one per child. Randomly arrange the circles (spaced apart) on an open area of the floor. If possible, stick the pumpkins to the carpet or floor with rolled pieces of masking tape on the back. Now turn on the stereo and explain that as long as the music is playing, everyone should circle around and through the pumpkin patch. But as soon as the music stops, each child should sit on a pumpkin. The game continues in this manner, with no elimination, until the kids are ready to move on to another activity.Guess who's the ghostIn this disappearing game, one child is temporarily escorted out of the room. Meanwhile, another child covers herself in a plain white sheet (another option is to drape the sheet over a card table so the child can simply duck under it). When the first child is brought back into the room, he tries to guess which of the other guests is the ghost. Keep playing until everyone's had a chance to be the guesser and the ghost.Spooky (but sweet) scavenger huntIt wouldn't be Halloween without tricks and treats  and the trick here is finding the treats. There's a bonus, too: The kids get to collect their loot in a customized treat bag. In one room, spend a few minutes helping the kids turn paper lunch bags into colorful treat totes by having them draw designs with crayons or nontoxic colored markers. As they finish their drawings, fashion a handle for each tote by cutting a strip from a large grocery bag and stapling the ends in place. Meanwhile, have a helper hide soft wrapped candies, small boxes of raisins, and little party favors in another room. When everyone's ready, bring in the kids and let the scavenger hunt begin. One tip: Reserve a portion of the candy so you can supplement any treat bag that ends up a little short.Return to our Halloween guide.

column1: BabyCenter Helps Parents Plan Summer Travel
column3: Hometown Travel Guide Helps Parents Plan Family Getaways; Provides Reader Recommended Hot Spots, Hidden Gems and Travel TipsSan Francisco, CA (June 30, 2006) -- BabyCenter, LLC, the leading online resource for new and expectant parents, has unveiled the BabyCenter Readers' Hometown Travel Guide  a list of 50 family friendly vacation spots across the country as recommended by BabyCenter readers.In an online survey of more than 1,500 parents from May 1 thru June 2, BabyCenter asked readers to share their favorite hometown destinations to shed light on why they feel these destinations are a great place for families to visit and to pass along local wisdom on the hidden gems not on the usual "must see" list for tourists.Survey results have been packaged in the BabyCenter Readers' Hometown Travel Guide and include a variety of hot spots for destinations large and small, ranging from wild life parks to museums and art centers. While popular cities such as New York, Miami and Chicago made the list, it also introduced BabyCenter readers to new places like Alamogordo, NM, Fort Madison, IA, Kalispell, MT, and Santa Claus, IN."The BabyCenter community is a diverse group of moms who are happy to share advice and tips with other parents on everything from travel to teething. It's an incredible network of supportive and interactive moms," said L. Jasmine Kim, chief marketing officer, BabyCenter. "When it comes to tips on traveling with families, you can't ask for better advice than from other moms about their hometown."With more than half of the parents spending between $500 and $2,000 for a week's vacation, the BabyCenter Readers' Hometown Travel Guide offers a variety of ways to help readers plan their vacation budget in advance, including links to lodging options such as RV parks, campgrounds and family friendly hotels, local hot spot admission details, and dining.The guide also revealed hot spots for couples taking their last baby-free vacation  also known as a Babymoon. Top destinations include the White Mountain Resort in Hudson, NH and the Hot Springs Pool in Aspen, CO. And, while the guide provides location information and links to helpful resources, it also includes fun tips on how to blend in with the locals from etiquette on ordering food, to greetings, and do's and don'ts.

column1: LGBTQ parents: Talking to your family about your plans
column3: The number of families with lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender parents is greater than ever before. But while the families that LGBTQ people create are increasingly accepted in the world at large, the families they come from might not be so welcoming."Family relationships are difficult, even now," says Jeff Levin, a licensed clinical social worker at the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Community Center in New York City."LGBT people who don't have supportive families sometimes question their own ability to become parents," says Levin. "They don't know if they have the skills, the temperament, or the patience. And without their own family to back them up, they feel they're already at a disadvantage."Struggles with family can range from outright rejection, where a family of origin simply won't accept their family member's sexuality, partner, or decision to become a parent, to more subtle tensions. For example, if one partner in a relationship is biologically related to a child via egg or sperm, sometimes relatives will treat that partner as the "real" parent. In her practice in Berkeley, California, psychotherapist Mary Bradford has heard of situations where family members ignore the partner, or won't use the parents' preferred terminology for their family. In one example, says Bradford, family members of a gay male couple who used one partner's sperm with a surrogate insisted on referring to the surrogate as the child's mother.But Bradford has also seen families become more accepting and loving. She cites the experience of one of her female clients, whose family rejected her when she married a woman and had a child. Despite open hostility, the woman stayed in contact, then began gently planning visits with the child. Eventually, her family members came around.And, Bradford says, never underestimate the power of a grandchild. "Having grandchildren really warms people up. That's a bond, and an important one, and it does change minds and hearts."If you're dealing with family who may not be supportive, there are some steps you can take to manage both the situation and your own expectations.Test the waters: Gauge how your family of origin feels about you becoming a parent. That helps you know how your child will be received and gives you some time to educate your relatives about LGBTQ families.Timing counts. If you're not sure how it will be received, don't drop your "We're pregnant!" announcement at your mother's 60th birthday party.If you have a close family member, share your plans with that person first. Then, if you anticipate an overall less-than-joyful reaction from your family to your news, strategize with your close ally and other helpful relatives so that when you do make your announcement, you won't feel alone.If you encounter antagonism or have an ongoing difficult relationship, you may be able to persuade family members to attend a meeting with an organization such as PFLAG, formerly known as Parents, Families and Friends of Lesbians and Gays, which has chapters around the country. Support staff at organizations like this can provide great perspective and mediate constructive dialogCome up with some tactful deflections for when people get a little too curious about how you're going to become a parent. If you don't want to get into the details of sperm donors, egg freezing, or adoption, a simple, "We're working with some experts and we're really excited" is enough.Give your relatives time, and persist in keeping a connection. If they live in a less-than-progressive community, they might never have thought about you having children, so it might take a while for them to come around.If your family can't be there for you, find allies where you can. Gay and straight friends, your own Facebook or WeChat group, online communities where you can vent freely  all can give you the emotional support you need.Show sources Hide sources PRRI. 2015. How race and religion shape millennial attitudes on sexuality and reproductive health. Public Religion Research Institute. Jones, Robert P. and Cox, Daniel. http://www.prri.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/PRRI-Millennials-Web-FINAL.pdf [Accessed December 2016]

Tax time: Flexible spending plans versus the childcare credit
column3: Daycare and childcare payments can take a big bite out of your paycheck. That's especially painful in a tough economy, when we're all looking for ways to cut expenses. Fortunately, you can recoup some of the costs by either enrolling in a flexible spending account (FSA) or taking the childcare credit at tax time.To qualify for either an FSA or the childcare tax credit, both you and your spouse must have earned income. Exception: One of you was a full-time student for five months of the tax year.If you work for a company that offers an FSA, here's how to figure out which option is best for you. Either way, it's like getting a sale price on childcare  something that's virtually never marked down.The childcare flex accountA flexible spending account for dependent care is not something you can set up on your own, but many companies offer one to employees. This type of FSA allows you to put aside up to $5,000 ($2,500 for married individuals filing separate returns) before taxes to pay for dependent care expenses.The amount is deducted from your paycheck and then reimbursed to you for qualified expenses  money you paid for services that enable you to work, such as at-home care (a nanny or babysitter) and care outside the home (such as daycare or after-school care). Note: In most cases, to obtain FSA reimbursement you'll have to provide receipts for payment from, and a social security number or tax identification number for, every care provider, including nannies and other babysitters.Because this is a "pretax" deduction, you won't have to pay federal, social security, Medicare, or state taxes on the amount. Your contribution can't exceed the income of the spouse who earns the least. So, to set aside the full $5,000 each year, each parent must make at least that much.An FSA essentially serves as a tax deduction, reducing your adjusted gross income (AGI). This may allow you to have more itemized tax deductions for the year and increase the amount allowed for personal exemptions.Do think carefully about how much money to earmark for your FSA, though, because you forfeit any amount that isn't used during the calendar year. For example, if you sign up to have $3,000 put in your FSA and you only spend $2,000 on childcare that year, you'll lose $1,000. In other words, $3,000 will be taken out of your pay but only $2,000 will be reimbursed.The childcare tax creditThe IRS offers a 20 to 35 percent kickback on up to $3,000 ($6,000 if you have two or more kids) of qualifying childcare expenses you accrued in 2016. If your AGI is $15,000 a year or less, you get the full childcare tax credit; if it's more than $43,000, the figure drops to 20 percent. So if you earn $45,000 a year and spend $6,000 on childcare for two kids, the tax credit equals just $1,200.Qualified expenses are defined in the same way they are for FSAs. And as with an FSA, those expenses can't exceed the earned income of the spouse who earns less.The best choice for youDepending on your financial circumstances, you may be able to take advantage of both an FSA and the childcare credit  but you can't claim the same expenses for both. For most people, however, it'll make financial sense to choose one or the other.Generally, the more you earn, the more you'll benefit from an FSA, particularly if you're at or above the 25 percent federal tax bracket. Taxpayers in the 15 percent federal tax bracket who have only one child and have qualified expenses of at least $3,000 may be best off with the FSA, too.For example, a married couple filing a joint federal tax return with a taxable income of $80,000 will save federal taxes of $1,250 (25 percent of $5,000) if one parent contributes $5,000 to a dependent-care FSA account. In addition, social security taxes will be reduced by $310 and Medicare taxes by $72.50.Lower-income families usually get less value from an employer-sponsored FSA and fare better with the federal tax credit. Of course, if your employer doesn't offer an FSA for dependent care, you'll want to take the tax credit.Ultimately, you may need to run the numbers to see which option saves you the most money. A tax specialist can figure it out for you, or you can do the math yourself using an online tool. Search for "dependent spending account calculator" (or similar wording) to find one.Learn moreFor more information, consult an accountant or try these IRS links:Frequently asked questions about the childcare credit and flexible spending accounts for dependent careThe Child and Dependent Care CreditForm 2441, Child and Dependent Care Expenses

column1: Planning your preschooler's birthday party: Choosing a theme
column3: Throwing a party with a theme adds to the birthday fun. Plus, props signify that the party is something special, not just another playdate, and choosing a theme makes decorating easy.The inspirationMany preschoolers will have ideas for the theme, so enlist the birthday child's help. Book, TV, and movie characters are popular, and you can buy a decorating kit with cups, plates, napkins, and banners.Preschoolers especially love it when their cake is decorated with their favorite character. Thomas the Tank Engine, Elmo, Dora the Explorer, Disney princesses, Bob the Builder, Winnie the Pooh, and Mickey Mouse are all appropriate for this age group.Outside the boxYou can also think outside the box and come up with your own creative theme. Throw a morning pajama party: Whip up pancake batter, put out sleeping bags, and invite everyone to wear their PJs while you make breakfast for them. Or celebrate with a teddy bear party: Ask the guests to bring their bears and spread out a picnic on a blanket. (Reassure them that they get to take their bears home when they go!)If you're feeling brave, try a messy outdoor art fest where you put the kids in old T-shirts and let them go crazy with big sheets of paper and bottles of paint.Color me happyA color theme is ideal for this age, and as a bonus, a theme revolving around your child's favorite color is easy to execute. Pick up some pink balloons, pink M&Ms, and pink plates, and you're ready to go. You can also invite your guests to wear pink to the party.

column1: Planning your preschooler's birthday party: Games and activities
column3: Preschoolers are easily delighted and entertained  and they're experts at free play. Pass out bottles of bubbles, sticks of chalk, and some balls, give them a patch of grass to run around on, and they'll be happy.Preparation is keyBut it's fun to incorporate a few special activities at a party. For 3-year-olds, prepare three or four activities, and for a group of 4-year-olds, five to six  that way if one game is a flop you can quickly move on to the next one. It's hard to know how long an activity will capture children's attention, though they can often burn through one in five to ten minutes. Here are some ideas for activities.Mini MichelangeloThis is a great age for an uncomplicated art project. Make several colors of homemade playdough, then ask the kids to create mini birthday cakes. (Remind them that these pretend cakes aren't for eating!)Roll out a long piece of paper, write "Happy Birthday" across it, and the kids can decorate it with markers and stickers before you hang it up. Pass out crayons, paper, and cookie cutters, and show them how to trace around the shapes.Music timeMost children this age love action songs and hand rhymes. Try "I'm a Little Teapot," "The Hokey Pokey," "If You're Happy and You Know It," "Here We Go 'Round the Mulberry Bush," and "Ring-Around-the-Rosy." Go through the songs first, demonstrating the actions, and then sing together.Free to be you and meDon't expect all kids to participate in games. Some 3-year-olds will be more inclined to wander off and kick a ball or color. Put out some picture books, trains, simple puzzles, and a dress-up box to keep them occupied.If you're hosting a party at the park, the play equipment will engage the kids, but you'll create a more memorable experience by incorporating a few activities. Play Follow the Leader or Hide and Seek. Invite everyone to bring their tricycles, kites, or buckets and shovels.Let me entertain youWhat about formal entertainment? If you're expecting a big group of guests or hope to chat with other parents, you could consider hiring an entertainer to keep the kids enthralled. Just bear in mind that some preschoolers find a clown funny while others will be frightened and reduced to tears.Costumes  even if it's Elmo  are typically what scare this age group. The kids will be most comfortable with someone who isn't heavily disguised with a mask or face paint and who will simply sing songs and dance with them.Bounce house?Preschoolers love bounce houses, but often their judgment hasn't caught up with their physical ability and they're likely to take too many risks. The last thing you need is a kid with a broken arm. So, if you do rent a bounce house, be sure to always have at least two adults supervising.

column1: Planning your preschooler's birthday party: Goody bags
column3: At this age, your young guests probably won't notice if you skip the party favors. If you do choose to buy them, steer clear of candy and small toys that kids can choke on.Less is moreConsider giving each child one nice item that will last awhile rather than many little things that will clutter up your guests' homes and likely end up broken. They don't have to cost much. You could give the kids a pair of fun socks, a stuffed animal, a sheet of stickers, a box of crayons, a bucket and shovel, a novelty bath sponge, a bike bell, or a paperback book.On a budget? You can make your own playdough and pass it out in plastic bags tied with colorful ribbon. Or bake dough ornaments using cookie cutters tied to the party theme  whether it's dinosaurs or cats or fairies.Double dutySippy cups also work well because kids can use them at the party and then take them home. Just be sure to write the children's names on them.Book wormsSome families do a book swap instead of goody bags or presents: Each child wraps and brings a book to the party and at the end everyone opens a book to take with them.Hide and seekBe sure to put the goody bags out of reach so little hands don't get into them before the party's end. But stash them in a place where you can see them or else you might forget to pass them out.

column1: Planning your preschooler's birthday party: Presents
column3: Presents are lots of fun for preschoolers, but a huge pile of them opened all at once can be overwhelming. Also, kids this age  especially 3-year-olds  are likely to snatch gifts from the guest of honor, and this can lead to trouble.The gift that keeps on givingUnless a guest requests that your child open a gift at the party, some parents choose to leave the present unwrapping for afterward. More and more, this is considered a socially acceptable option, especially for very young kids who easily melt down during gift opening. You might spread the process out over a week so your child opens one gift a day  especially if you throw a big party and are left with a mountain of presents.One more tip: Put the presents in a place that's out of the children's reach.To gift or not to giftSome families are experimenting with gift-free birthday parties, suggesting that guests bring handmade cards instead of toys. Some families do a book swap at the party instead of presents: Each child wraps and brings a book, and at the end, each kid gets a book to take home. This is one easy way to take care of the presents and goody bags in one fell swoop.Giving thanksBe sure to send out thank-you notes. A cute and simple option is to take a photo of your child with all his new presents, print it out, and then mail or email it to all the guests. If you're sending them by mail, you can involve your child in the process by allowing him to decorate the thank-yous with stickers.

column1: Planning your child's fifth birthday party: Presents
column3: Planning your child's fifth birthday party: Birthday presentsFor most 5-year-olds, a birthday party is about presents first  and then friends, cake, and games. Kids this age often talk for weeks beforehand about what toys they hope their friends will give them. It's not uncommon for the birthday kid to tell his friends what he wants.Your job is to make sure the excitement around presents doesn't get out of hand. Before your guests arrive, you should come up with a plan. Where will guests put the presents when they arrive? It's best to designate a place that's out of reach of little hands.Timing's everythingWhen should your child unwrap gifts? These days, it's not uncommon for families of 5-year-olds to put off the present opening until after the party. Many 5-year-olds are territorial about their stuff, and some parents don't want to deal with eight kids all fighting to play with the same shiny new race car. Plus, if you're hosting a crowd, you might decide your guests can't sit still long enough to watch your child open 15 or 20 gifts. If you're holding the event at a party place outside the home, a tight schedule might not allow for presents.Then again, guests enjoy watching a child open his birthday presents, and it's a good chance to teach your child gift-receiving etiquette. Before the party, talk to your child about saying thank you  even for things he doesn't like or already has.Early in the party, as guests are arriving, can be a great time for gifts at this age. This way, your child isn't nagging you to open presents throughout the entire party and he can move on to enjoying his time with his friends.After the presents are unwrapped, you can put the new toys away until after the party. With luck, your child will agree to this without any fuss, because he'll be excited to play with his friends. Another popular time for gifts is after cake. Whatever you plan to do, be sure to tell your child ahead of time.To gift or not to giftSome families choose to have a no-presents party, thinking that it's easier on everyone, that it reduces the clutter in their home, and that it's better for the environment.Giving thanksMailing thank-you notes after the party is standard, and if you involve your child in the process you can begin to teach him how to properly thank friends. One fun option is to have your child pose for a photo with all of his new toys and then use it as a thank-you card. Is it acceptable to simply email the photo and send a digital thank-you? That's debatable. Some might say it's inconsiderate and lazy, while others would say that you're saving trees. It's your call!

column1: Planning your child's sixth birthday party: Presents
column3: Six-year-olds are fully tuned into the idea that they'll be getting birthday presents at their party. They like to get stuff and they have preferences for brands and types of toys. Kids this age are likely to get more excited about the plastic superhero figurine from a friend than the beautiful cake baked by mom.Before the party, you'll want to designate a spot for gifts  ideally one that's out of reach of little hands. You'll also need to decide when to open presents.Timing's everythingIt's become more and more common for families to decide that it's easiest to open presents after the party, for two reasons: You avoid conflicts between children fighting over the new toys, and your guests don't have to sit still through a long gift-opening session. If you're holding the event at a party place outside the home, you might be on a tight schedule that doesn't even allow time for presents.But if you're expecting a small group, opening presents at the party is a great option. The kids who picked out specific gifts for your child will enjoy watching their present being opened. Plus, unwrapping presents in front of others is a good opportunity for your child to learn gift etiquette. Before the party, talk to your child about saying "thank you" after opening each gift. Explain that it will make the gift giver feel sad if he says "I don't like this!" or "I already have this!" By age 6, most kids will be responsive to this lesson.Some families do presents one by one as guests arrive. This way your child isn't nagging you to open presents throughout the entire party and he can move on to enjoying his friends. After the presents are unwrapped, you can put the new toys away until after the party. With luck, your child will agree to this without any fuss because he'll be excited to play with his friends.Another option is to open the presents after cake, just before the guests leave. If one of your guests can't stick around for the gift opening, they're free to go. Whatever you plan to do, be sure to tell your child ahead of time.To prevent a free-for-all, hand gifts to your child one at a time. One idea for solving the "Open mine first!" dilemma: As kids arrive, have them pull a number out of a bowl and tape it on their present. Later, gifts are opened in numerical order.To gift or not to giftSome families choose to have a "no presents" party, arguing that it reduces clutter in their house, is better for the environment, and makes things simpler for everyone.Giving thanksAt this age, your child is ready to take on some responsibility for sending thank-you notes. It's important to reinforce that thank-you notes are the rule for birthdays and holidays, so try to build time for it into the week following the party. One easy approach is to print out a card and have your child decorate each one with markers and stickers and then sign her name.Strapped for time? Some parents write generic thank-you cards before the party and put them in guests' goody bags. Other families send out thank-you emails in lieu of paper cards. Is this acceptable? That's debatable. Some might say it's inconsiderate and lazy; others would say that you're saving trees.

column1: Plan B -- a single mom's decision to go it alone
column3: I'm in my ob-gyn's office, feet in the stirrups. Dr. Bakas peeks up over the paper sheet draped across my knees and pulls his gloves off with a snap. "So? Do you want a cigarette?"My friend Bev laughs, as does the nurse, but I try not to because I don't want to jiggle or move or do anything to disrupt those tiny little sperm as they make the long journey up through my uterus to my little waiting egg.They've already had to do a lot of traveling. I bought them from the Scandinavian Cryobank, which shipped them from Denmark. They're from Olaf (not his real name), who's 22 and blond, blue-eyed, and tall.Olaf (well, his sperm) arrived packed in dry ice a week before I ovulated, so he hung around with me as we waited. He became my dinner companion. I set him up in his large round container on the chair across the table from me. I told him about my day.A part of me thought it'd be lovely to not have to drink both glasses of wine  and he could have done more than just agree with me all the time. But then I took him into the living room to watch TV, and he didn't complain when I kept changing the channel. We became pals, Olaf and I. We took pictures.Dr. Bakas hasn't done this before, though he did see the procedure when he was a resident. It's nothing, he said to me when I first talked to him about artificial insemination. We can absolutely do it here.So now the deed is done. Intrauterine insemination. It has a higher success rate than the vaginal insemination I could have done myself at home. And I'll take any advantage I can get."If it's going to happen, it's happening right now, so just lie here for ten minutes. Let the magic begin," Dr. Bakas says, nodding as he and the nurse leave. Bev and I look at each other. Yes, I think, I'm getting pregnant right now.(I don't know where I got off thinking that way. I knew even then that my chance of getting pregnant through artificial insemination was only 5 to 25 percent per try.)I'm so excited it's hard to remember how reluctant I was about all this.For years I had stuck faithfully to another plan.The PlanThe Plan: Live life. Get married. Have kids. (I was hoping for two, but could have been talked into one or five or 20.)In grad school at 36, I thought, This is good! But where's the rest? The men? The dating?At 37, graduated, I turned to my friend Rebecca and said, That's it. I'm getting married.She had found a wonderful husband by combining hard work, sheer determination, and a little luck. So I did what she did: Yahoo, Match, Nerve. Never mind that I'm shyer than Rebecca, and not nearly so slender, and I don't have her brilliant red hair. Still, I dated up a storm at 37 and 38. I met many nice men. And at 38 I began to settle in with Juan, a screenwriter who was between jobs.He wanted kids, too  though it became more and more clear that he wanted them later, after he hit it big. I pulled out a BabyGap ad for strength, put it on the floor beside me and told him: We need to break up.And then one day, watching the high school students in the summer program I run, I thought back to being 16. And I realized, holy smokes, I'm Thirty-Nine and One Half years old.The kids went back inside to their classes, but I stayed in the sun and twisted a lock of hair around and around my finger. Well, I thought, I haven't asked Steve out yet. I could ask if he wants to go for a drink sometime. I also have a date coming up next week with a friend of a friend of a friend. It's not so bad. Don't panic.But I was panicking. Because it struck me that even if I did fall in love right then, say with Steve (or the guy next week, it didn't matter), and he fell in love with me, we'd have to wait a year or so to get engaged and then a year to plan the wedding and then, well, he wouldn't be ready to have kids right away...I mean, jeez, I'd be 50 before we could even try for a baby.I'm going to be alone, single, and childless for the rest of my life, I thought. This isn't the life I imagined when I was 16, sitting around listening to Love, soft as an easy chair and reading those romance novels, one after another.He was supposed to have rescued me by now. He was supposed to have surrendered to my feminine wiles long ago: my doe eyes, my blonde tresses.I stood up, fluffed my tresses, and faced the facts with my doe eyes.He isn't coming.I am absolutely on my own.I'd suspected this to be my fate even as I dreamed of the other, more romantic life. When I was a teenager my parents said, "You'd better lose that weight or you're not going to find a boyfriend." And embedded in this warning was the fate-worse-than-death scenario that my mother's sister was living: 40, single, childless.They shook their heads with pity. Poor Aunty Hanne.I felt it like a curse on my head. Be thin! Or die alone!Somewhere deep inside me I knew I'd be there, at the threshold of 40 and alone. I just knew it. And I swore as I watched Hanne get older and older that no matter what, I wouldn't miss out on having a child. Even if I had to go to some random bar and leave with a random guy and ravish him in some random motel. Then disappear.Plan BIt'd be more dramatic to say that I immediately got on the phone, ordered some sperm, and got on with it. But it took another several months to officially move from The Plan to Plan B. Most especially there was the deep, hollow sadness to be worked through in watching The Plan fail.Then, of course, there were things like money to be considered. And Rebecca helped me with a dirty little secret fear: Up until then it'd been hard to find a man ...but with a kid in tow, would it be impossible?Come on, she said. It's not like the old days. Look around you: Over 40, single with a baby, is hardly shocking. Just move on with your life. Do what you want. You have the rest of your life to find a man. This you have to do right now.Eventually I understood. I am absolutely on my own...for now.At the doctor's office, after I keep still for ten minutes, Dr. Bakas lets us go. At home I lie on the couch beneath my front room window. The couch where Olaf's sperm lounged for most of the seven days they were with me. I prop my butt up a little and focus on getting pregnant, just in case Dr. Bakas isn't right about the instantaneousness of insemination.Two days later, while I'm visiting a friend, waves of dizziness almost knock me over. There's a strange pinging deep in my pelvis and  most strangely  an awful metallic taste in my mouth. I know I'm pregnant. I just know I am. It may not stick, but at this moment, I know I am.It does stick, and my daughter Kaj arrives nine months later, one day after her due date. My miracle first-try baby. Meant to be, my mother says.Kaj is long and thin  8 pounds, 9 ounces. She's yanked out of me after 35 hours of labor and a near cesarean (which was most definitely not part of The Plan or even Plan B). But I can tell you this for sure: Epidurals are the miracle of the 20th century, and I have the best obstetrician in the entire world.

column1: Life Insurance & Estate Planning
Should health plans pay for birth control?
Do you plan to use cloth or disposable diapers?
Did you plan to quit your job after having a baby?
Are you planning to give birth without using pain medication?
9 months, week 4: When did your baby first sit in a highchair and join you for family meals?
Planning your preschooler's birthday party: What your child is ready for
column3: Keep it simpleBut before you put down a deposit on a bounce house and a clown, keep in mind that a simple party is often more fun for kids this age. A big birthday bash can overwhelm 3- and 4-year-olds and leave their parents exhausted. Preschoolers' expectations are low, and they tend to accept uncritically whatever food you serve and favors you hand out. They're perfectly happy with a relaxed party with snacks, cake, and one special element, like an art project.Go with the flowThat said, a big shindig might be more fun if you have a large extended family or live in a neighborhood full of kids. The secret to planning for a large group is to create a low-key, low-pressure atmosphere. If you throw a basic backyard bash or a party at the park that's easy to plan and execute, you'll be relaxed and your child will feel at ease and be less likely to dissolve into a puddle of tears before cake time.Be presentYou can also help the birthday child get through the day by insisting on an early bedtime the night before. Make sure to give lots of hugs and kisses throughout your child's birthday. The most important thing is for you to be there with plenty of love and attention, rather than getting distracted with tending to your guests.Start a traditionIf you haven't already incorporated a tradition into your child's birthday, this is a good time to start one. A tradition can be as simple as special candleholders you put on the cake every year or a hat your child always wears at cake time. Or maybe at the end of every year's party, you put on your child's favorite music and everyone boogies (a great opportunity for shooting video!). Traditions make the day more meaningful and incorporate a familiar element into an event that's bound to be a bit overwhelming.

column1: Planning your child's fifth birthday party: What he's ready for
column3: A 5-year-old looks forward to a birthday for weeks. He knows the day of his actual birthday  and the day of his party, if it's different. He knows what theme he wants. He might know what friends he wants to invite (though this list can change daily). He may enjoy talking nonstop about the party plans.Mini party plannerYou can encourage your child's enthusiasm by involving him in the planning. Give him a project, like coloring the invitations. You can also use his keen interest as an opportunity to talk about party etiquette. Tell him that it's nice to greet guests at the door and thank them for coming when they leave. Your child will likely listen and follow through, because the typical 5-year-old wants to please.But it's also important to know that your child's enthusiasm for his birthday can trick you into believing he's ready for a big bash. Five-year-olds are known for giving off the impression that they're self-contained and capable  but they can actually be quite intimidated in unfamiliar situations. Developmental psychologists often point to 5 as an age when children are more withdrawn, while 4 and 6 are more outgoing ages.Location, location, locationAn at-home party  something you have probably done before  might be the best fit for your 5-year-old. But it all depends on your child. For some energetic, rambunctious 5-year-olds, this is a great age to head to a party place where an instructor leads the kids through activities. But hosting the neighborhood kids at a local park can be just as fun  especially since you can be fearless about taking on all kinds of messy projects, like decorate-your-own cupcakes and chocolate-pudding finger painting. If you live near the coast, the beach is a great option because kids can build sand castles and hunt for shells and driftwood.Follow the leaderWhatever you plan, keep in mind that the kids will probably need you to lead them through activities  5-year-olds are typically in preschool and used to looking to an adult for guidance when engaging with a group of kids. This is a compliant age that responds well to direction.

column1: Planning your child's fifth birthday party: The invite list
column3: Crowd controlMany kids are in preschool when they turn 5  a few are already in kindergarten  and you might be tempted to invite the entire class. It's thoughtful and generous to include all the kids so nobody ends up feeling left out. (Some schools have a policy against handing out party invites at school unless everyone's invited.)These big all-inclusive shindigs can be great fun  especially if you enlist the help of friends and family or if you hold the event at a party place where everything is taken care of. But before you start to plan for a crowd, make sure that you and your child are up for this  and realize you have alternatives. Your party will be more manageable and your little one will likely behave better if you restrict your list to six to eight kids.Revolving friendsKeep in mind that 5-year-olds  especially those who are settling into a new school for kindergarten or who are in preschool for the first time  change friends regularly. One day Olivia is your child's best friend and the next day you'll hear that Olivia rejected your child on the playground.You definitely should ask your child which children she wants to invite, but be prepared for her to change her mind every few days. For this reason, you might consider sending invites out as late as possible. Once the guest list is finalized and the invites are out the door, let your kid know that she can't change her mind.Meet the parents?Should you include the parents at this age? Five-year-olds are right at the cusp of being ready for a drop-off party. It really depends on the children you're inviting and how well they know you. At this age, it can be best to leave it up to each parent whether or not to stay.Small outingOne low-key alternative is to take your child plus one or two friends on a fun outing: pizza and a movie, a picnic and the zoo. This is an especially good approach if your kid is one of the many who has become surprisingly solitary, antisocial, and overwhelmed by large groups as she approaches this birthday milestone. While 4 and 6 are ages when most kids are outgoing and meet new situations with enthusiasm, 5-year-olds can be withdrawn and easily intimidated. It will be better for everyone if you plan a birthday celebration that's suited to your child's current temperament.Crafty invitesYour 5-year-old will probably enjoy helping with the invitations. She could draw a picture that ties into the theme, then you could make photocopies or scan it on the computer to make invites. Many 5-year-olds can write their friends' names on the envelopes. Even if she only does two or three, it will give her a sense of pride. If you don't have time to make invites, you and your child can shop for cards or pick a design for an email invitation together.

column1: Planning your child's fifth birthday party: Choosing a theme
column3: The inspirationFive-year-olds love to have their passions incorporated into a party: ballerinas, pirates, Batman, Cinderella, SpongeBob. This makes it easier to plan  themed plates, napkins, cake decorations, and party favors are readily available online and at party supply stores. And kids go nuts for anything that's emblazoned with their favorite character.But you could also steer your child toward his more distinctive interests. Maybe he loves to help you tend plants in the backyard  you could throw a garden party. The guests could make tissue paper flowers, plant bulbs in small pots to take home, and snack on garden-fresh veggies. Or your child might be crazy about camping  you could pitch a few tents in the yard or at the park and serve hot dogs and s'mores. You can host a tea party and invite guests to bring their dolls or stuffed animals.Crazy for costumesChildren this age love to dress up. You could suggest that they come as kings and queens or their favorite superhero. It's also fun to help the kids make their own costumes at the party. At a cat party, you could make masks with whiskers and ears from construction paper, or for a pirate party you can help the kids create hats and eye patches out of construction paper and then swords from cardboard covered with foil.Do-it-yourself decorationsYou can try making some decorations yourself, with your child as your assistant. Mobiles, paper chains, and balloons with funny faces are all easy to do. There's a lot you can make with old cardboard boxes: a rocket ship for a space party, a mini house for a doll party, or a treasure chest for a pirate fest. You can tape boxes together to form the rocket, house, or chest ahead of time, and the kids can decorate it at the party. No time or money for fancy decorations? Concentrate on making the table look nice with colorful napkins, fresh flowers picked from your yard, and maybe a few of your child's toys that tie into the theme.

column1: Planning your child's fifth birthday party: Games and activities
column3: Be preparedWith 5-year-olds, your party will go more smoothly if you have what may seem like a ridiculous number of games prepared  10 to 12. The kids may run through them more quickly than you expect, or one or two may flop. You'll want to be organized because kids this age are in preschool and look to adults for instruction when they're in big groups. If there's a lull between games, you might be faced with a group of kids screaming, "What should we do?" or even worse, "This party is boring!"Warm them upFives can be slow to warm up to a new situation. And they can also be solitary  especially when they're feeling shy. As guests trickle in, start with a few quiet activities that keep everyone busy doing the same thing but that don't require them to cooperate. Something hands-on like making things with pipe cleaners or clay might be a way to warm up. Once everyone has arrived, you could pull the kids together and read the birthday kid's favorite book or a story that ties in with your theme. (Choose the book before the party!)Let the games beginAfter the kids seem comfortable, start with some interactive games. (Kids this age usually aren't ready for team games.) You can rename the classics to fit your theme: Pin the Patch on the Pirate, Musical Beach Towels, The Queen Says. It's fun to create your own "feely bags" filled with dried beans, pennies, bars of soap  and then pass them around the circle and let kids guess what's in them. You can play some music and do a birthday march through the house. Pass out musical instruments and sing a song.Tucker them outWhile 5-year-olds might start off quiet and composed, they will quickly become restless and be ready for high-energy play. Try Red Light/Green Light, Follow the Leader, Leap Frog, Mother May I?, and Hide and Seek. Simply running amok on the lawn can help burn off some energy  though an adult might need to get this started.Get some helpTo make it easier on yourself, you could hire an entertainer. Kids this age will do best with someone who has a mix of tricks up his sleeve: a puppet show, face painting, and balloon animals. Five-year-olds are more comfortable than younger kids with characters in costume  many will have visited theme parks where they took a picture with Mickey Mouse or Snoopy  but it's safer at this age to stick with an entertainer who isn't disguised by a mask or heavy makeup.On a tight budget? Tap your friends or the parents of your party guests to see if they can do face painting, or play the guitar and lead the kids in song.

column1: Planning your child's fifth birthday party: Goody bags
column3: You're not obligated to pass out goody bags. But most 5-year-olds will have been to parties where this is the norm, so if you don't your guests will probably notice and a few might say something.Bags full of trinkets are common, and 5-year-old partygoers love lots of loot  but there are more environmentally friendly alternatives that send your guests home with less clutter. Consider writing the children's names on their party favors. Kids this age can become upset if they think their things are getting lost or mixed up.InspirationA good place to start is your theme. Can you come up with a favor that ties into it? If you host a garden party, send home bulbs that the children can plant. For a butterfly fest, wrap a packet of flower seeds, a few gummy worms, and a butterfly sticker in netting. Art party? A small watercolor set or a coloring book and box of crayons will certainly get used.Double dutyAnother great option is to do a craft project with the kids and make that the going-home gift. Kids this age are capable of taking on more complex projects. For a princess party, you can cut out crowns from construction paper or craft foam and then the kids can glue on fake gems. Or how about making kites from paper plates at a kite-flying party?Photo opAnother possibility: The kids can decorate photo frames made from squares of card stock with a 4-by-6-inch hole cut into the center. Then you can take a photo of all the party guests or of each child with the birthday kid and print it immediately (if you have a digital camera kit equipped to do so) or send the photo in a thank-you note.Book wormsSome parents do a book swap instead of party favors (and sometimes in lieu of gifts, too). Each child wraps and brings a book, and at the end of the party, each kid gets to open a book to take home.

column1: Planning your child's sixth birthday party: What he’s ready for
column3: Birthday highsIt's a classic trait of 6-year-olds to want to go first, to be loved the most, and to receive the most of everything. At this age, a birthday party is thrilling because it puts the birthday child at the center of attention. Six-year-olds get very excited as their party draws near and love joining in the planning - making invitations, helping to bake a cake, and choosing party favors.Birthday lowsBut while 6-year-olds thrive in the period leading up to the party, they sometimes struggle on the actual day. They might burst into tears or storm off in anger when they find themselves competing with a group of exuberant kids jockeying for the biggest piece of cake, grabbing at piata candy, or trying to jump the highest in the bounce house.Everyone's a winnerThis might sound like a nightmare, but actually it's quite easy to keep everyone happy if you think ahead. Play games that allow everyone to win, frost all the cupcakes with the same color of icing, and pass out favors that are identical.Grown-up grade-schoolerThis is the first year when you can safely plan a drop-off party, because most 6-year-olds separate easily from their parents. You can also lead the kids in more complicated art projects than in past years and feed them a wider variety of foods.Six is a great year to meet up at a party place where staff will lead the children in games and songs.
