This works great for 6-year-olds, who tend to listen to their teachers but resist their parents. If you host the party at home, the secret to success is a well-planned mix of games, art projects, and free play.

column1: Planning your child's sixth birthday party: The invite list
column3: Big bashMost kids are in kindergarten when they turn 6. If you're ever going to host the entire class at a party, this might be the year to do it. In kindergarten, children's relationships aren't fully established, so your child might not have an obvious circle of friends to invite. Also, friendships are stormy, so the list of close buddies frequently changes. Sometimes it's easier to include everyone rather than deal with your child's ever-changing roster of friends. Plus, big parties can be a lot of fun, especially if you have extra adults on hand to help or if you can hold the event at a party place where the staff runs the show.A more low-key option is to bring treats to school and celebrate your child's birthday in the classroom. Ask the teacher if this is allowed and if there are any rules or restrictions  some schools might not allow sugary treats. Also, the teacher can tell you about any allergies students have. If you'd like, you can also talk to the teacher about incorporating an art project or other activity into the classroom celebration. The kids might like making your child birthday cards with paper and stickers you bring.Twice the fun, half the priceOne great idea to help cut the costs and workload for a large party is to find a partner in the kindergarten class  another family with a child who has a birthday near your child's. By hosting the party together, you can split expenses and responsibilities.Small shindigOf course, a small at-home party with five or six guests is a relaxed and comfortable option, and one that children this age  especially if they're shy  will still enjoy. If you live on a street full of kids, you could just invite the neighborhood gang to the party.If you decide to invite only a few students from your child's class, it's good to know that kindergartners are chatterboxes, and the news of a birthday party spreads fast. To avoid hurting the feelings of those who aren't invited, it's better not to pass out invitations in class (this is often forbidden by school policy for this reason). Instead, you can mail invites or send out an email.Meet the parents?Should the guests' parents stick around for the party? Six-year-olds are often at their worst with their own mothers and fathers, so the party might go more smoothly if parents just drop their kids off. Most kids this age separate fine from their parents, but if any have anxiety about being dropped off, then invite the parent to stay. You can always use an extra helper!

column1: Planning your child's sixth birthday party: Choosing a theme
column3: Get inspiredThemes that tie into a TV or movie character are big hits with many 6-year-olds and simplify the planning for you. You can buy a decorating kit with cups, plates, napkins, and banners emblazoned with your child's favorite  whether that's Buzz Lightyear, Hello Kitty, Word Girl, Tiana, or Superman.But you can also come up with a theme by looking at your child's more unique interests  such as painting, cooking, or kittens  and spinning one of them into a party. No matter what theme you and your child decide on, you can tap into her imagination to help bring it alive. Six-year-olds are masters at thinking outside the box and your child will be your best source of creative ideas.Have a tea partyYou and your child might have lots of fun brainstorming ideas for an Alice in Wonderland theme, for example. Put out snacks labeled "eat me" and "drink me," play Pin the Smile on the Cheshire Cat, decorate Mad Hatter hats, and plant little flowers in pots that the kids can take home.Follow the yellow brick roadFor a Wizard of Oz party, you can hang a crepe-paper rainbow from the ceiling, create a yellow brick road with a roll of paper, put a pair of red shoes on the birthday girl, make a lollipop tree out of cardboard (when the guests leave, they can pick one).Love Legos?Or how about a Lego fest? The kids can get creative with heaps of blocks spread across the floor, build cars to race down a ramp, and guess how many Legos you put in a clear glass jar. You can even make a Lego cake by baking a rectangular sheet cake, topping it with eight cupcakes, and then frosting it with icing in a bright primary color.Get creativeSix-year-olds love painting and drawing, so your guests might like an art fair where you give them a quick art class and then set them free to create something. While everyone is eating cake, you can put the artwork on display and give each one an award or certificate. When the parents come to pick up their kids, they can browse the gallery.

column1: Planning your child's sixth birthday party: Games and activities
column3: Be preparedThe key to a successful 6-year-old birthday party is a well-planned mix of games, activities, and free time. You probably need about eight to ten games, which may sound like a lot, but your guests might run through them more quickly than expected or one or two could flop. Children will likely spend five or ten minutes with a simple game, but they'll sometimes become absorbed in an art project for 15 to 20 minutes.As guests trickle in, it works well to start off with an activity they can do individually. One good option is to spread out art supplies on a table, because 6-year-olds love cutting, pasting, coloring, and painting.Let the games beginAfter everyone arrives, you can move into games. Six-year-olds aren't emotionally well suited to competitive games since they often can't bear to lose. They're known for cheating and trying to change the rules, and if that doesn't work, dissolving into tears. This is why you're better off with interactive games like Simon Says, Mother May I?, Red Light/Green Light, Hide and Seek, and Leapfrog. You can also ask your child's teacher what games the kids like at school.After some high-energy play, your guests might be ready for a quieter activity. The preschool urge to dig in dirt often returns for 6-year-olds, who enjoy exploring with their hands. If you can deal with the mess, the kids will love making mud pies in the backyard or at the park. A messy art project  finger painting with chocolate pudding, creating art with glitter and glue, drawing on the cement with chalk  might also be a big hit.After the kids have had cake, they'll likely be ready to tear around. If you have a backyard, you can put out some jump ropes and balls and let them go nuts. The children can play on their own, but it's smart to have a few games up your sleeve just in case conflict arises and you need to distract them.You could also rent a bounce house or walk to a neighborhood park and arrange for their parents to pick them up there.Get some helpAnother way to top off the party is with an entertainer. Online, you'll find a wide assortment  from princesses who bring trunks full of dress-ups, to farmers who can set up mini petting zoos with goats and chickens in your backyard, to magicians who wow the kids with tricks. By age 6, kids are used to performers, so you don't need to worry about them getting frightened.On a tight budget? Tap your friends or the parents of your party guests to see if they can do face painting, or play the guitar and lead the kids in song.

column1: Planning your child's sixth birthday party: Goody bags
column3: Six-year-olds tend to be takers  not givers  and they will love any party favors you hand out before they go home. In fact, they may have been to enough parties by now that they'll expect a party favor. Just make sure that each child gets exactly the same thing and the same amount because 6-year-olds are experts at spotting unfair situations: "Ella's ball is pink and mine is red. I want a pink one! That's not fair!"Six-year-olds love to play with the little whistles, yo-yos, erasers, and magnifying glasses that are often stuffed in a goody bag. But often these break quickly and end up in the garbage can within a day. One good option is to give just one durable or useful item that ties into the theme: pink bubble bath for a princess party, a toy race car for a Hot Rod fest, a packet of wildflower seeds for a garden theme, cat- and dog-shaped cookie cutters for a pets theme.Double dutyAnother idea: Give the kids an art project so they can make their own going-home gifts. Children will enjoy decorating T-shirts with puffy paints, stringing necklaces with brightly colored macaroni, weaving construction paper placemats, and making wooden spoon puppets, egg carton caterpillars, or paper bowl turtles.

column1: Planning your 7- or 8-year-old's birthday party: What your child is ready for
column3: Seven and 8 are wonderful party ages. Big kids are open-minded, sociable, curious, and generally well behaved. They've been to a lot of birthday parties by now and get excited about fresh twists on the traditional party elements - ice cream sandwiches instead of a cake, take-home art projects instead of goody bags.Game onAt this age, they're ready for group and competitive games; relay races are always a huge hit. They're able to follow more complex directions, which means you can organize a game of Capture the Flag. And they're comfortable with the idea of a drop-off party. Parents who feel like they've been throwing the same birthday party for the past several years may welcome all of these new developments.Lucky sevenSeven-year-olds are less likely than 8-year-olds to beg for a party at the laser tag place or bowling alley. Many will be content with a party at home or a park or rec center. Seven-year-olds tend to be a bit quieter and easier to manage than the more loquacious, boisterous 8-year-olds. If you have a big shindig in mind, it might be better to do it at 7 than at 8.The great eightEight-year-olds are looking for novelty. Going out to an ice cream parlor, pizza joint, or paint-your-own-pottery place is particularly popular at this age. Of course, a home party can be a success with 8-year-olds, but you'll need a lengthy list of elaborate projects and games to keep them entertained.Fun for the whole familyYou could throw an afternoon backyard barbecue and invite neighbors, family, and school friends and their parents. The kids will like it if you section off a children's corner and fill it with toys, dress-up clothes, and arts and crafts projects. You might also want some organized games, and possibly a bounce house or entertainer, so the adults can hang out while the kids jump around or watch magic tricks.

column1: Planning your 7- or 8-year-old's birthday party: The invite list
column3: Eight is enoughEight or so is a good number of guests for a 7-year-old's party  though you can probably manage ten or 12 or even more if you have another adult helper. Kids this age typically behave well at parties; they listen to adults and get along with friends.Eight-year-olds by contrast are often physically wild and boisterous. The party will go more smoothly if you limit the number of guests to eight or fewer. Then again, it's usually safe to overinvite since grade-schoolers' weekend schedules are filled with activities. Not everyone you invite will be able to make it.Most kids this age want to invite school friends. It's easiest to pass out invitations at school, but keep in mind that the invitations could end up languishing in your child's backpack with a week-old banana peel. What's more, kids this age have been known to dangle an invite in the face of someone who hasn't been asked.To prevent hurt feelings, don't pass invitations out at school. Mail or email them instead.Coed celebration?You can invite both boys and girls, but at this age it often works best to have an all-girl or all-boy party. Boys  especially 8-year-olds  might feel strongly about preferring no girls, while girls more often willingly include boys. The stereotypes often prove true, with girls preferring quieter activities such as art projects, while boys like high-energy games such as relay races and balloon tosses.Meet the parents?With both 7- and 8-year-olds, a drop-off party is the norm and all the kids will probably separate easily from their parents. On your invitation, make the drop-off and pick-up times clear.Helping handIf you don't have relatives or friends to help, contact one of the guest's parents ahead of time and ask if she'll stick around to help. Often you can reach an "If you help me at my party, I'll help you at yours" agreement. When parents drop off their children, put out a piece of paper near the door where they can write down a contact number in case of emergency.The invitesIf you make the invitations by hand, most 7-year-olds will enjoy assisting, while 8-year-olds can often do it themselves. Kids this age are known for trying to write neatly, and their handwriting might be even better than yours. Of course, you can always make the invites on the computer or send out emails  your child can help with this as well.

column1: Planning your 7- or 8-year-old's birthday party: Choosing a theme
column3: Keep it simpleSeven and 8-year-olds have definite interests  Star Wars! Hannah Montana! Horses!  so choosing a theme will likely be a piece of cake. If your child wants the party to revolve around a pop culture icon, it's easy to buy a party kit with cups, napkins, decorations, the works.Get creativeBut with this age, the theme at a party is often less about characters appearing on paper cups and more about creative activities  so try to think less about how the decorations can tie into the theme and more about what the kids can do that will relate to it.How about a puppet party? Have the kids make puppets with wooden spoons and paper bags and plates and then put on a show for their parents at pickup. Or throw a Hawaiian luau: The children can make grass skirts with green crepe paper, munch on skewers of fresh pineapple and chicken teriyaki, and learn how to hula dance from an instructor. Or put on a dance party: Hang a disco ball, put on some music, and let the kids move and groove. A CD featuring the birthday child's favorite songs is the perfect party favor.Geek outKids this age are curious and love a science-themed party. Create a chemistry station by covering a table with a vinyl tablecloth, filling clear plastic cups with water and food coloring, and putting out some baking soda and lemon. Construct a volcano with clay and make it explode using red food coloring, baking soda, and lemon. You can also go on a bug hunt, play with slime, and pass out magnifying glasses as party favors.Tire 'em outFor a high-energy group, throw a mini Olympics, with an Egg Toss, Tug of War, and tricycle, crab walk, potato sack, and three-legged races. You can divide the kids up into teams, hand out medals, and even hold an awards ceremony when the parents pick up the kids.

column1: Planning your 7- or 8-year-old's birthday party: Goody bags
column3: Most 7- and 8-year-olds are willing to let go of traditional elements of a birthday party. If you don't pass out goody bags, they probably won't put up a fuss  especially if you hand out prizes for games instead. You can make sure everyone gets a prize while also acknowledging the winner by offering treats to all guests but allowing the winner to pick first.Of course, goody bags are still lots of fun, especially if your party has a theme you can tie into. Try to use your wits rather than lots of money. If your party has a sports theme, you could pass out medals (made with cardboard, foil, and ribbon). Or take instant photographs of the kids  especially if they're in costume  and hand them out at the end. If you're hosting a group of girls, you could paint their nails before they leave. Many boys would love a cardboard sword covered in foil or spray-painted gold.

column1: Planning your 7- or 8-year-old's birthday party: Presents
column3: At ages 7 and 8, presents are a big deal. Your child will know exactly what she wants for her birthday and she will probably share her list with her friends. Often groups of friends are collecting the same toys, and they're excited about each other's stuff. When the day of the party arrives, everyone will be anticipating the present-opening session, and parents can make sure everything goes smoothly by having a plan ahead of time.Timing's everythingYou'll want to decide where guests should put the presents when they walk through the door  ideally in a place that's out of reach of little hands. You'll also need to pick a time for gift opening. Right after cake is often good. Your child can pass out goody bags at the same time. After she opens a friend's gift, she gives the friend a bag  this way there's an exchange and everyone is happy.Be sure to talk with your child beforehand to make clear when the gift unwrapping will take place. If you don't do this, your child may nag you about it throughout the party or start ripping presents open when you're not looking.To prevent a free-for-all, hand gifts to your child one at a time. You can solve the "Open mine first!" dilemma by writing numbers on pieces of paper and putting them in a bowl. As kids arrive, have them pull out a number and tape it on their present. Later, gifts are opened in numerical order.Is it acceptable to open presents after the party? More and more this is considered okay. If you're hosting more than ten kids, the present opening can go on too long. And if you're holding the event at a party place, the schedule might not allow time for presents. But some of your child's friends might ask for their presents to be opened. If this happens, you could let your child unwrap the gift near the end of the party.Giving thanksRemind your child to say something nice about each gift she opens and to say thank you even if it's a toy or book she doesn't want or already has. Children need to learn the etiquette of unwrapping gifts, and a birthday party is a great place to learn.At this age, your child is ready to take on some responsibility for sending thank-you notes. It's important to reinforce that thank-you notes are the rule for birthdays and holidays, so try to build time for it into the week following the party.Some parents who are really strapped for time write generic thank-you cards before the party and put them in guests' goody bags. And some families send out thank-you emails in lieu of paper cards. Is this acceptable? That's debatable. Some might say it's inconsiderate and lazy, while others would say that you're saving trees.

column1: Let's Play! Leaf Peeping & Roll-Over Plan
column3: Leaf PeepingAt this age, your baby seems endlessly curious about the world and excited by seeing new things. You're probably spending lots of time out and about, looking for new sights to introduce him to.Appropriate for: 6 weeks to 3 monthsSkills developed: VisualWhat you'll need: A few brightly colored leaves; tapeThe next time you take your baby out for a walk, collect a few brightly colored leaves to show him. (If it's not fall, pick a few leaves in unusual shapes and colors.) Tape the stems of the leaves to the sunshade of his stroller: They make wonderful natural mobiles, as even the slightest breath of wind sends them turning and twirling above his little head.Safety note: If your baby has learned to grab, make sure the leaves aren't within reach.Roll-Over PlanAt almost 3 months old, your baby is really working on gaining control over the way she moves. This simple indoor or outdoor exercise will help get her ready to roll.Appropriate for: 2 to 6 monthsSkills developed: Gross motor, sense of touch, body awarenessWhat you'll need: A fairly large blanketOn a warm day, take your baby to the park or out into your backyard and spread a blanket on a patch of grass or soft ground (or simply do this in your home). Take off as many layers of clothing as weather permits, as babies seem to feel freer to move around when they find themselves in the buff. If you have some cloth diapers, you might even spread those under her and let her go diaperless for a few minutes.Lay your baby on her stomach or back, and help her roll over (or let her roll herself over if she's capable of it). Then roll her over again yourself, so she's back in the original position. Continue in one direction until she reaches the edge of the blanket  to give her a sense of getting somewhere  then lift her back to the center again. Keep doing this as long as your baby enjoys it. Babies delight in new perspectives, so if she seems to savor a certain position, lie down next to her and check things out together.Remember: Each baby develops at a different pace, so if yours isn't quite ready for this week's activities, don't worry  just try them again in a few weeks.See all our Baby ActivitiesVisit your 2-month-old, week 4 pageShow sources Hide sources AAP. 2012a. Baby's vision development. American Academy of Pediatrics. http://www.healthychildren.org/English/ages-stages/baby/pages/Babys-Vision-Development.aspxAAP. 2012b. Movement: Birth to 3 months. American Academy of Pediatrics. http://www.healthychildren.org/English/ages-stages/baby/pages/Movement-Birth-to-Three-Months.aspx

column1: Health insurance during pregnancy: How does my health plan work?
column3: How does a health insurance plan work?There are many different kinds of plans. Some have deductibles, some don't. Some use copayments, some use coinsurance. Most employer or government sites have tools that can help you compare costs among plans and understand your benefits.In addition, the Affordable Care Act requires all health insurance plans to provide you with two easy-to-understand documents that explain their specifics: Evidence of Coverage and a Summary of Benefits and Coverage.Here are the most common terms you'll see and what they mean:Allowed amountThe allowed amount is what your insurer decides it will pay for a medical service. This is generally based on the amount usually charged for the same or a similar medical service in your area, which is known as the usual, customary, and reasonable (UCR) amount.Your insurer may only cover a percentage of the allowed amount for a service or visit, even if your provider charges more. In this case, you must pay the difference.For example, if your doctor charges $200 for a visit and your insurer says the allowed amount for the visit is $100, you are responsible for the additional $100 in addition to your copay or coinsurance.CoinsuranceThis is the portion of your medical costs that you must pay after you've met your deductible. For example, once coinsurance kicks in, you may pay 30 percent of the cost of a visit (that's $30 for a $100 visit) and your insurer would pay the other 70 percent. (The percentage you pay would be higher if the provider is out of network.)However, your insurer will only cover the percentage of the amount that they consider reasonable for the service in your area. This is the allowed amount. So, in this example, if your doctor charges $200 for a visit and your insurer says the visit should only cost $100, then the insurer will pay $70 and you will pay $130 ($30 + $100).DeductibleThis is the amount you have to pay for medical services each year before your insurance will start to cover a portion of the cost. That means you may have to pay the full amount for some services until you have paid the total amount of your deductible. (Some plans have separate deductible amounts for hospital stays, ER visits, medications, etc.)Some plans will pay for certain services (such as annual checkups and preventive care) regardless of whether you have met your deductible. These services may be covered in full or they may require a copayment from you.Evidence of CoverageEvidence of Coverage is a document showing detailed information about your benefits and coverage. It specifies the services that will and will not be covered, the actions you have to take to receive the benefits, and what you'll have to pay and when. The document also explains the process for appealing decisions made by the insurance company. Flexible Spending Account (FSA)A flexible spending account and a health savings account are both pretax money taken from your paycheck, but with a flexible spending account, you have to use all the money in it by the end of the year. FSAs are only available with employer-sponsored insurance plans.Your employer may grant you a grace period of an extra couple of months to use the money in your account or allow you to carry over up to $500 a year to use in the next year, but they are not required to do either of these things.At the end of the year or grace period, you lose any money left over in your FSA. So it's important to plan carefully and not put more money in your FSA than you think you'll spend on healthcare costs within a year.Grandfathered planGrandfathered plans are older health plans that are not required to provide all of the benefits and services mandated by the Affordable Care Act ("Obamacare"). To qualify, the plan must have existed on March 23, 2010, and not been significantly changed since then.HMO (Health Maintenance Organization)An HMO will usually only cover visits to doctors in its network. It generally won't cover out-of-network care except in an emergency. HMOs usually require you to get a referral from your primary care physician for a visit to a specialist other than your ob-gyn.You'll pay a set copayment for each doctor or ER visit. Premiums are generally lower than for a PPO plan.Health Reimbursement Account (HRA)A health reimbursement account is a bank account that your employer puts money into for you to use for healthcare costs. These accounts are usually connected with high-deductible plans for which you and your employer pay less on premiums.Your employer passes that savings on to you by putting money into your HRA. Neither you nor your employer must pay taxes on this money. As with other accounts, you get a list of medical services and medications that you can pay for with this money.The money in an HRA account can carry over from one year to the next, although your employer can limit the amount that carries over. If you leave your job, your employer keeps the money in the account. Health Savings Account (HSA)A health savings account is a bank account you can use to pay for medical costs if you're enrolled in a high-deductible health plan. You can decide how much money to have taken out of each paycheck (before taxes are deducted) and put in your HSA, up to a certain annual limit. (Your employer may contribute some money to your account as well.)You use the bank card for this account to pay for medical services and medications. (You'll get a list of services that are included.) The advantage of these accounts is that you don't have to pay taxes on the money you spend on health costs. That means you're actually paying about 20 to 30 percent less for these costs, depending on your tax rate.Unlike with a flexible spending account, you don't have to spend all the money in your HSA by the end of the year. The account stays with you from year to year and even if you leave your job. You have the rest of your life to use whatever money is in the account, as long as you use it for a "qualified" medical expense.These include nearly all medical expenses, not including premiums (which are already paid with pretax dollars). You can even use the money for over-the-counter medications if you have your doctor write you a prescription for them.High-deductible health planHigh-deductible plans feature higher deductibles than traditional health insurance plans. The plan is often paired with an HSA or HRA, healthcare accounts that help you pay less for medical costs.One advantage of this type of plan is that you generally pay a lower premium.Of course, it also means you'll be paying the full cost for some or all health services until you hit that deductible amount. After you've paid enough to cover your deductible, you generally pay a certain percentage of further medical costs (called coinsurance) until your hit your annual out-of-pocket maximum.In-network and out-of-networkIf a provider (a doctor, specialist, hospital, lab, or pharmacy) is in your network, it means they have agreed to provide a discounted rate to your insurer. Some plans (usually HMOs) will only cover services from providers in their network. In that case, you have to pay the full cost if you go to a provider outside the network. Other plans cover services from out-of-network (or "non-preferred") providers but will ask you to pay a higher copay or coinsurance percentage for them.Out-of-pocket maximumThis is supposed to be the highest amount your insurer will ask you to pay for medical costs for the year. Once you have paid this amount of money, your insurer is supposed to cover 100 percent of any other medical costs you have for the remainder of the year.However, read the fine print to find out what is included in this amount. It almost always includes your yearly deductible, but it doesn't necessarily include premiums or out-of-network costs. (Some plans have a separate, higher out-of-pocket maximum for out-of-network care.) And you will still be responsible for costs that are more than the allowed amount for any service.Note that the out-of-pocket maximum is higher for couples and families than for individuals. Pre-authorization or pre-certificationIf your insurance company requires pre-authorization or pre-certification for something, they are asking for proof that the particular service, drug, or equipment is medically necessary.These are generally not routine things (like annual checkups). They're more likely to be procedures like CT scans, elective services like substance abuse residential programs, or special medications. Some insurers require pre-authorization before you're admitted to the hospital for delivery.Your healthcare provider should know when something requires pre-authorization and will contact your insurance company to obtain it. The insurance company has a list of items it will authorize. If the requested treatment is not on the list, it will conduct a review to determine whether it will cover it.Pre-authorization does not mean that the entire cost of the service will be covered by insurance. Your deductible and co-insurance or co-pay will still apply. But failing to get pre-authorization could mean that you'll wind up paying the full price.By the way, your hospital will have you register online in advance of your arrival for delivery. This is called a pre-admission certification and is not the same as a pre-authorization.PPO (Preferred Provider Organization, also called open access plan)A PPO is a plan that coordinates a network of providers who agree to provide healthcare at reduced rates. This type of plan allows you to visit any healthcare provider you like without a referral from a primary care physician. You don't have to choose a provider within the network, but you'll pay less if you do.You'll probably have to meet an annual deductible before the plan starts covering a portion of your bills. You usually have to pay a copay for certain services or cover a certain percentage of the total charges (coinsurance).PremiumThis is the amount you pay each month (or each paycheck) to the insurer for your coverage. The total for the year is your annual premium. This amount will be higher if you have a partner or children on your plan. (It may also be higher if you work part-time.) If you have insurance coverage through your employer, your company will usually cover part of the premium, so it's likely to be lower than the amount you would pay for a plan on the marketplace.Qualified health planA qualified health plan is an insurance plan that's certified by the government. These plans must provide the basic health benefits required by the Affordable Care Act and set limits on expenses like deductibles and copayments.If you choose a health plan that is not qualified, you'll have to pay the same fee to the Internal Revenue Service that people without health insurance coverage must pay. (All healthcare marketplace and employer-sponsored plans are qualified.)Special enrollment periodUnder normal circumstances, you can sign up for insurance only during the annual open enrollment period (usually November through January). However, you may be eligible for a special enrollment period if you lose your current coverage or experience a "qualifying life event" (such as a marriage or birth). This gives you 60 days to sign up for a marketplace plan or 30 days to sign up for an employer-based plan.Summary of benefits and coverageThis is a short explanation of your plan's benefits and coverage, which is helpful when comparing plans. The document should be in plain, easy-to-understand language and should include an explanation of healthcare terms.Show sources Hide sources HealthCare.gov. What Marketplace health insurance plans cover. https://www.healthcare.gov/coverage/what-marketplace-plans-cover/ [Accessed February 2016]HealthCare.gov. Health coverage if you're pregnant or plan to get pregnant. https://www.healthcare.gov/what-if-im-pregnant-or-plan-to-get-pregnant/ [Accessed February 2016]HealthCare.gov. Exemptions from the requirement to have health insurance. https://www.healthcare.gov/health-coverage-exemptions/exemptions-from-the-fee/ [Accessed February 2016]

column1: After maternity leave was over, did you go back to work as planned?
Do you plan to use plastic or glass baby bottles?
Your pregnancy: 16 weeks
Your 4 3/4-year-old: Body image
Are liquid diets safe for new moms?
Best foods for new moms: Energy boosters
column3: Life with a newborn is exhausting. It's usually impossible to get enough rest and exercise in those first few demanding months, and it's difficult to eat well.But as all-consuming as caring for an infant can be, it's important to take care of yourself too. Choosing healthy foods  and following a few simple eating strategies  will help keep you energized through your busy days and nights.Start with a balanced diet, and drink plenty of water. Try to make time to sit down for a quick snack or meal  even if you have to put the baby down or hand her off to your partner or a helper for a few minutes.And make every meal count. Here are some of the best strategies for getting an energy boost from your food. If you need more guidance, the USDA's MyPlate website offers a customized daily food plan based on your age, gender, and activity level.Begin with a better breakfastProteins (such as eggs and yogurt), and complex carbohydrates (like whole grain bread and cereals) are better breakfast choices than simple carbohydrates or sugar. So instead of reaching for a plain bagel, a bowl of sugary cereal, or a piece of white toast  all simple carbs  try a smoothie made with fruit and yogurt, a bowl of oatmeal or whole grain cereal, or scrambled eggs on whole wheat toast.Simple carbs cause your blood sugar to spike and then crash, leaving you feeling sleepy. Complex carbs give you longer-lasting energy, help you feel full longer, and provide more vitamins and minerals, explains pediatrician James Sears, coauthor ofThe Baby Book."A protein-rich, complex carbohydrate-rich breakfast is very important  and probably the opposite of what most people do," he says.Eat small meals throughout the dayRather than eating three large meals, aim to eat five smaller meals to keep your energy up, Sears suggests."It's a better way of eating," he says, because it keeps your energy level on an even keel the whole day long, rather than seesawing between hunger and fullness.If you're having trouble eating one meal a day, let alone several, try keeping the fridge stocked with easy snacks or quick small meals high in protein or complex carbs. Grazing throughout the day will be easier if you have a tasty selection of high-energy snacks to choose from.Try whole wheat bagels or toast with peanut butter, edamame, hummus on pita bread, cheese and crackers, trail mix with nuts and dried fruit, and yogurt with fruit. Resist the urge to dietNobody likes to wear their maternity clothes after the baby has arrived. But even if you're frustrated with the pace of your postpartum weight loss, now is not a good time to skip meals or drastically cut back your caloric intake."It's important not to worry about your weight right now," says Debra Gilbert Rosenberg, author of The New Mom's Companion,who advises new mothers to focus on sustaining their strength rather than achieving weight loss goals.Wait until your milk supply is well established, you've fully recovered from pregnancy and childbirth, and your healthcare provider has given you the green light before you slowly work on shedding extra pounds. (See our diet for healthy postpartum weight loss.) Aim to lose about a pound and a half a week, and give yourself at least 6 months to a year to return to your pre-pregnancy weight.But even then, try to resist the urge to crash diet or impose strict weight loss goals, especially if you're breastfeeding. If you're nursing, you'll actually need to eat about 500 more calories a day than you did before you became pregnant in order to maintain your milk supply."Your body is going to [lose weight] the way it's going to do it, and you have to respect that," says Rosenberg. Losing too much weight too quickly after giving birth saps your energy and might even affect your milk supply. Learn more about a healthy diet while breastfeeding.Drink, drink, drinkIn the first few weeks after you have your baby, dehydration will make any fatigue or sleepiness you're experiencing worse. So it's important to guzzle water like it's going out of style. "Drinking a lot of liquids is probably the easiest thing people can do" to keep their energy up, Rosenberg says.Keep a water bottle handy around the house, in your diaper bag, and in the car or stroller, so you can stay hydrated no matter where you are. If you're breastfeeding, you might be extra thirsty so make sure to drink about 13 8-ounce glasses of water or other unsweetened, noncaffeinated beverages every day.Don't rely on caffeine or sugarIt's tempting to reach for a cup of coffee whenever you're exhausted, or grab a candy bar when you need quick energy. But be careful not to rely on caffeinated drinks or sugary snacks to keep you going when you're running on empty.Both caffeine and sugar will give you a quick burst of energy, but once that initial surge is gone, you'll be left feeling even more tired than before.Caffeine can make your baby irritable and restless too, so limit your caffeine intake to 300 milligrams a day  about two 8-ounce cups of coffee. Grab a piece of fruitA piece of fruit is the best bet when you need a quick pick-me-up, according to registered dietitian Jo Ann Hattner. Fruit gives you a burst of energy but doesn't cause a later "crash" like junk food laden with refined sugar.Plus, fruits like apples, oranges, peaches, and pears are high in fiber, which helpskeep your digestive tract moving. Best of all: Most fruit requires no prep work or cleanup, and is easy to eat on the go.Choose energy bars carefullyAn energy bar can be helpful as an occasional way to sustain yourself between meals, especially when you're away from home and need a quick fix.But be cautious about reaching for an energy bar regularly, says Hattner, because they're often surprisingly high in calories and sugar. Check the label to make sure the energy bars you choose are low in sugar and fat and high in fiber, protein, and carbohydrates.Food can only do so muchFinally, know that even the most energy-packed food can't counteract sleep deprivation. If possible, take a quick nap the next time you're feeling weary, rather than turning to food."We tend to eat, thinking that will give us energy," Hattner says. "It may just be that you need a nap."Show sources Hide sources ARHP. 2008. Counseling postpartum patients about diet and exercise. column1: Getting the most from HIV medication
column3: Approved by the Society for Maternal-Fetal MedicineHow can I stick to my HIV treatment plan?The most important thing to do is probably the simplest: Go to all your medical appointments. That way, your healthcare provider can help you monitor the medications you're taking, watch out for any side effects, and supervise your general condition.A treatment plan for HIV consists of medications that make up antiretroviral therapy (ART). There's a lot you can do to help yourself stay on track:Talk with your provider about your plan, so you can develop the one that works best for you. Ask for a written copy of the plan, and make sure it details each of your medications, including how and when to take them.Find out what side effects to expect and how to deal with them.Understand how the treatment plan protects you and your baby from infection and helps prevent the virus from becoming resistant to other medication. Knowing this may motivate you to stay on the plan.Talk to your provider about any challenges you face that could affect your ability to take HIV medication. Maintaining a treatment plan can be harder if you're also dealing with substance abuse or alcoholism, unstable housing, mental illness, relationship problems, or other issues.Use a seven-day pillbox to organize pills for each day. Fill it at the start of every week.Tell your provider about your daily schedule so you can plan your medication to fit in with your life, rather than organizing your life around medication.Take your pills at the same time as something else that you do regularly each day  watching the news, brushing your teeth, or arriving home from work.Use your phone to set reminders, either with the alarm or by using an app. The AIDSinfo HIV/AIDS Drug Database App bookmarks HIV medicines, allows you to add your own notes about a drug, and has a daily pill reminder feature.Ask your family members, friends, or co-workers to remind you to take your medicines.Always have access to your medication and keep a spare supply at work. If you're traveling, pack enough to last for the whole trip.Join a support group, either online or in your community. Getting advice and encouragement from others going through the same thing helps.How can I get the most out of HIV medication?Take HIV medication exactly as your healthcare provider tells you. That means taking it:at the right timewith food, or before or after meals, depending on the advice you've been givenevery day, including weekends, holidays, and even when you're in laborTaking medication consistently can be difficult. It helps to keep track of what you take and when on a computer, phone, or in a notebook. The important information to track includes:the name of each medicinethe dosethe number of pills to takewhen to take the medicationWith ART, you'll likely take several pills a day, each with its own requirements.Missing a dose, or taking it at the wrong time, can result in an increase in the amount of HIV in your body, putting your health at risk and increasing the chance of passing the virus on to your baby.Drug resistance is also a problem with regularly missed doses. Drug resistance means certain drugs no longer work to reduce HIV in the blood.What should I do if I forget to take my HIV medication?Don't panic. Call your healthcare provider. In most cases, your provider will say to take the medicine if you just missed it.Discuss medication at each appointment with your provider. Tell your provider if you're having difficulty following your medication regimen.Don't forget to mention any side effects you're having. Side effects from HIV medicines are a major reason why sticking to a treatment plan can be difficult.Let your provider know if your treatment plan is too complicated to follow. Your provider may simplify your regimen to include fewer HIV medicines or to reduce the number of times a day you need to take them.What else does my healthcare provider need to know?Tell your provider about any other medications you take. This includes other prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products. Other medicines or supplements may interact with HIV medication. A drug interaction can reduce or increase the effect of HIV medicine or cause side effects.Tell your health care provider about anything that makes it difficult to stick to your treatment plan. For example, lack of health insurance and alcohol or drug abuse can make it hard to follow HIV treatment. If needed, your healthcare provider can recommend resources to help you address any issues you have before you start treatment.Visit the Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine's website for more information and to find an MFM specialist near you.Show sources Hide sources ACOG. 2012. column1: Your pregnancy: 35 weeks
Your pregnancy: 32 weeks
Diet for healthy post-baby weight loss
column3: Eager to get back into shape now that you're no longer pregnant? For long-term success  and to keep yourself feeling good along the way  keep these tips in mind.Don't start dieting too soonYour body needs time to recover from labor and delivery. Give yourself until your six-week postpartum checkup before you start watching your calorie intake and actively trying to slim down. And if you're breastfeeding, experts recommend that you wait until your baby is at least 2 months old before you try to lose weight. (If you're a nursing mom, you may also want to read our article on a healthy breastfeeding diet.)Starting a diet too soon after giving birth can delay your recovery and make you feel more tired  and you need all the energy you can muster to adjust to life with your newborn. In addition, if you're nursing, dieting can affect your milk supply. If you're patient and give your body a chance to do its work, you may be surprised at how much weight you lose naturally, especially if you're breastfeeding.Be realistic about weight lossKeep in mind that you may not be able to return to your exact pre-pregnancy weight or shape. For many women, pregnancy causes permanent changes such as a softer belly, slightly wider hips, and a larger waistline. With this in mind, you might want to adjust your goals a bit. For a reality check, see our photo gallery of real post-baby bellies.Postpartum exercises: Introduction Play VideoPlayMuteCurrent Time 0:00/Duration Time 0:52Loaded: 0%0:00Progress: 0%0:00Progress: 0%Stream TypeLIVERemaining Time -0:52Playback Rate1ChaptersChaptersdescriptions off, selectedDescriptionssubtitles off, selectedSubtitlescaptions settings, opens captions settings dialogcaptions off, selectedCaptionsdefault, selectedAudio TrackFullscreenThis is a modal window.Caption Settings DialogBeginning of dialog window. This modal can be closed by pressing the Escape key or activating the close button.Our short postpartum exercise videos are designed to help you get back into shape  and to easily fit into your busy, new-mom routine. See all baby videosEmbrace exerciseThere's no magic pill to help you lose weight: A healthy diet combined with regular exercise is the best way to shed the pounds  and to keep them off. And it's important to exercise while trying to lose weight to ensure you're losing fat instead of muscle.Once you're ready to begin losing weight, start by eating a little less and being more active  even if you're just taking a quick walk around the block with your baby in the stroller.Find out whether your body is ready for exercise and visit our postpartum fitness area for information on getting back into shape. Lose weight slowlyDon't go on a strict, restrictive diet. Women need a minimum of 1,200 calories a day to stay healthy, and most women need more than that  between 1,500 and 2,200 calories a day  to keep up their energy and prevent mood swings. And if you're nursing, you need a bare minimum of 1,800 calories a day (most nursing moms need more like 2,000 to 2,700 calories) to nourish both yourself and your baby.If you're breastfeeding, you'll want to make sure to take it slow  losing weight too quickly can cause a decrease in your milk supply.Too-rapid weight loss can also release toxins that are stored in your body fat into the bloodstream  and into your milk supply. (Toxins that can make it into your bloodstream include environmental contaminants like the heavy metals lead and mercury, persistent organic pollutants like PCBs and dioxins, and solvents.)Weight loss of about a pound and a half a week is safe and won't affect your milk supply if you're nursing. To achieve this, cut out 500 calories a day from your current diet (without dipping below the safe minimum) by either decreasing your food intake or increasing your activity level.Eat up  and take your time!With a new baby and schedule, it can be hard to find the time to eat. But skipping meals can make energy levels lag  and it won't help you lose weight. Many moms find that eating five to six small meals a day with healthy snacks in between (rather than three larger meals) fits their appetite and schedule better. (A small meal might be half a sandwich, some carrot sticks, fruit, and a glass of milk.)Don't skip meals in an attempt to lose weight  it won't help, because you'll be more likely to eat more at other meals. And you'll also probably feel tired and grouchy.Even if you've never been much of a breakfast person, keep in mind that eating breakfast can help keep you from feeling famished  and tired  later in the morning, and it can give you the energy to be more active.In addition, numerous studies show that skipping breakfast can sabotage your weight loss efforts. According to the National Weight Control Registry, which has tallied the successful strategies of dieters who have lost an average of 66 pounds and kept it off for 5.5 years, 78 percent of the dieters eat breakfast daily.Slow your eating down, too, if possible. When you take your time eating, you'll notice that it's easier to tell when you feel full  and you're less likely to overeat. Be choosy about foods and drinksResearch shows that consuming low-fat milk and dairy products and choosing whole grain products like whole wheat bread and whole grain cereal can help you lose weight. Other good choices include low-fat, high-fiber foods such as fruits (like apples, oranges, and berries) and raw vegetables (like carrots, jicama, and red pepper strips) for healthy snacks.Other ways to squeeze in more fruits and veggies: Make fruit (or veggie) smoothies, use fruit or vegetable salsas or vegetable reduction sauces (sauces made from pured vegetables) over fish or chicken, add shredded carrots to your sandwich, try grilled vegetables, and try pured vegetable soups. (Pureing your soup makes it creamy without having to add cream, which is high in calories and saturated fat. It's also a great way to eat veggies you might not ordinarily eat on their own.)Fat has twice as many calories as carbohydrates or proteins, so trimming the extra fat from your diet is probably the easiest way to cut calories. Look for low-fat or fat-free dairy products (you don't need to drink whole milk in order to make quality breast milk!), choose broiled or baked rather than fried foods, and limit your intake of sweets, which have extra calories from sugar and fat.Keep in mind, though, that fat is an important nutrient, so your goal isn't to eliminate it from your diet. In fact, including some fat at each meal will help you stay full and keep you from overeating carbohydrates. (Too many calories from any source  fat, protein, or carbs  can lead to weight gain or keep you from accomplishing weight loss.)The trick is to choose "good" fats rather than "bad" fats. The best fats are mono- and polyunsaturated fats, like those in canola oil, olive oil, avocado, olives, nuts and seeds, and fatty fish like salmon. The oils to avoid are saturated and trans fats, which can contribute to heart disease and perhaps diabetes, and can be transferred to breast milk, too.Saturated fats are found in meats and dairy products, and trans fats are typically found in many fried foods, snack foods, and baked goods. (Food labels specify which kinds of fats the products contain.)Finally, although you should be drinking about 8 or 9 cups of fluids each day, watch what you drink  a surprising number of calories can be hidden in juice, soda, and coffee drinks.Daily food plan for healthy post-baby weight lossThe food plan below adds up to 2,200 calories a day for breastfeeding moms. For non-breastfeeding moms, it totals 1,800 calories a day. Use this as a rough guide  your individual calorie needs will vary depending on your weight, metabolism, and activity level, and also on how much you're breastfeeding.View and print daily food plan.Show sources Hide sources American Academy of Pediatrics Committee on Drugs. 2001. column1: Your pregnancy: 29 weeks
Tips for helping your toddler adjust to travel
column3: New sights and sounds can be overwhelming to a young child. Vacation excitement can quickly turn to temper tantrums if you try to do too much too soon, so set realistic expectations and let toddlers soak up the experience at their own pace.Bring a blankie and cuddly toyA favorite blanket, special sheet, burp cloth, or stuffed animal can help your little one feel safe and secure. It can ease his anxiety about getting to  or being in  a new place.While keeping track of yet another item may seem like an extra hassle for you, clutching something soft and familiar will keep your child happier and more pleasant to travel with. Have a replacement lovey on hand in case the original gets lost.Start  and end  your day earlyTraveling with a toddler is not about sleeping in or staying out late. Young children are at their best earlier in the day, so plan to travel, sight-see, or explore in the morning. Afternoons and evenings are a good time for playing outdoors or relaxing back at your hotel.Respecting your child's inner clock will make her less likely to throw a tantrum in the car, the street, or a crowded museum.Establish a routine and stick to itTravel can wreak havoc on a toddler's daily routine, and your little one may get upset if his physical needs for regular eating and sleeping are not met. Keeping your child's nap and meal schedule perfectly on track may be impossible, but he'll be a happier traveler if you establish a routine.This doesn't mean watching the clock the whole time you're away from home  eating meals and taking naps at the same time each day may be all the routine he needs to feel comfortable in his new environment.Changing time zones can complicate the adjustment process, and children do get jet lag, but not to the same extent as adults. A well-rested child  or adult, for that matter  copes better than a tired one with time changes, so have your whole family rest up before you travel.To minimize the effects of jet lag, plan to arrive at your destination in the evening and stick to your usual bedtime routine: For example, give your child a bath, read him a book, and put him to sleep at his usual bedtime in the new time zone.If you're in, let's say, London and it's 7 p.m. there, put him down to sleep even if it's eight hours ahead of his normal bedtime. It will take a few days to adjust. Eat familiar foodsToddlers are notoriously picky eaters, and it's hard enough finding foods they like at home, let alone while you're traveling. You may be looking forward to sampling the local cuisine at your destination, but your child may be less excited about it.If you're going out to a restaurant, bring a supply of your toddler's favorite foods (such as goldfish crackers, O-shaped toasted oat cereal, fruit, or peanut butter and jelly sandwiches) to keep her satisfied and entertained while you enjoy your own meal.Stay close to home baseYour child's mood may be more unpredictable than usual when you're traveling, so it makes sense to establish a home base you can return to quickly and easily. Short jaunts away from your accommodations are less likely to tax your child's patience. And if the weather turns foul, someone gets sick, or your toddler just wants to nap, you can quickly head back to the room.Schedule running-around time for toddlersAfter being cooped up in a car, plane, or stroller all day, most toddlers are eager to be let loose. New walkers especially hate being confined, so spend time every day at a park or playground where your child can release some pent-up energy. A bonus: The more he races around during the day, the better he'll sleep at night.Expect the adjustment to take several daysNew faces and surroundings can be scary for a young child and make her cling to you more than usual. Combine fear with a dose of jet lag, a strange bed, new food, and all the other disruptions of travel, and you may end up with a child who's fussier and more demanding than usual.Once you arrive, expect to spend extra time making your child feel safe and secure in her new surroundings. After all, you're the best security blanket your child can have.

column1: Freezer facts
column3: Most parents can't live without a microwave oven. But another appliance  your freezer  is an unsung kitchen hero. You can buy food economically in bulk, such as meats, fish, bread, and apples (for pie making), and store it until needed. Or prepare a large batch of soup stock or a casserole and save it for later in meal-sized containers. And you can freeze leftovers such as soup or stew for quick and convenient future meals.Your freezer is also a handy place to store ingredients for the quick, nutritious types of meals kids love, from fish sticks and hot dogs to vegetables and, of course, desserts like sorbet, berries, and frozen yogurt. Not least, freezing is a great way to keep foods fresh longer. In fact, it's actually better to freeze nuts and breads (sliced before freezing) than to keep them in the pantry.To be safe and retain maximum flavor, remember these guidelines:Pay attention to temperatureTo prevent harmful bacteria from growing, don't let hot food cool down on the kitchen counter at room temperature. Instead, cool leftovers in the refrigerator. Cooling food first also prevents large ice crystals from forming during freezing, which can ruin flavor and texture.Divide large quantities of cooked food into smaller portions. Keep soups and stews to about three inches in depth per container, and divide meats into pieces that are two- to three-inches thick.Freezer temperatures should be between 0 and 8 degrees Fahrenheit.Wrap properlyPackaging counts when it comes to freezing food. Wrapping food well prevents freezer burn, which can affect texture and flavor. Freezer burn happens when frozen food starts to dehydrate. Look for plastic bags or plastic containers that are sold as "freezer safe." If you plan to reheat a frozen item in the same container, be sure it's safe for freezer-to-oven or freezer-to-microwave use. Don't wrap acidic foods, such as tomatoes, directly in foil, as the acid can react with the foil to produce an unusual flavor. Wrap as follows:Breads: It's fine to freeze bread in its original packaging, or put it in a plastic bag with the air forced out.Cooked vegetables, soups, casseroles: Use tight-sealing plastic containers.Fresh vegetables: Plastic zip bags  carefully sealed and with the air squeezed out work best.Meats: Double wrap them, first in freezer-safe plastic wrap and then in aluminum foil (use the heavy-duty kind) or freezer paper.One drawback to freezing is that it can change a food's texture. Frozen raspberries don't have the same crunch as fresh ones, so rather than serving them by themselves, it's better to use them in other ways, say as a dessert topping or in a smoothie. And a cream sauce that's been frozen on its own may separate on reheating. It's less likely to do so if mixed with pasta, and if it does separate, it won't be as noticeable and will still taste fine. Select the right locationFreeze meats and leftovers at the rear of the middle or lower shelves, where it's coldest  temperatures in the door fluctuate too much and aren't quite as cold. The door is best for storing juice concentrates and smaller items, such as packages of frozen vegetables or fruits. Some people like to organize the freezer by placing different types of foods (meats, breads, veggies) in specific areas, especially if space is tight, so they'll know at a glance where to find things. Avoid stacking packages in the freezer until their contents are fully frozen.Label everythingEven if you think you'll be using a frozen item right away, it's a good idea to mark the contents and date on the container. You can also write down the quantity and reheating instructions if someone else will be doing the reheating. Scribble right on aluminum foil with a waterproof or permanent marking pen. Or if you're using a dish, attach the information to the dish on a piece of masking tape. If you're a list maker or are superorganized, you can also keep a master list of freezer contents on the freezer door. Some people find this helps them plan meals and shopping lists.Defrost safelyFreezing smaller portions means you can defrost with less worry about bacteria. For instance, if you have a huge piece of meat, such as a turkey, the core can still be frozen while the outer surfaces get too warm. Always thaw a large item in the refrigerator rather than at room temperature.You can also defrost frozen foods in the microwave (set on "defrost") or in continuously running water that's cooler than 70 degrees Fahrenheit. Vegetables and some frozen foods (such as fish sticks) can be defrosted during the cooking process. Check package labels if you aren't sure.Limit length of storageFor safety and taste, foods shouldn't be kept in the freezer indefinitely. Below are recommended storage times for some commonly prepared foods. For additional storage times, see the University of Nebraska's "Freezing Recommendations for Commonly Prepared Foods".Meats: meatloaf, meatballs, roasts, cubed or chunky meat, ham, turkey, chicken, fishStorage time: one to three monthsCombination dishes: rice or spaghetti dishes, lasagna, chow mein, soups Storage time: three monthsBreads: rolls, sweet rolls, loaf of bread, coffee cake Storage time: three to six months

column1: Avoiding common pregnancy discomforts when you're on the road
column3: How can I relieve bloating, gas pain, and heartburn while traveling?When you're on the road, it can be hard to maintain a healthy diet and a regular eating schedule. Chances are you'll be eating out more, eating on the run, resorting to fatty fast-food meals, and eating foods you're not used to.Changes in time zones will shift your mealtimes. If you fly across country, you could find yourself eating supper at what would be midnight back home. As a result, travel can worsen the bloating, gas, and heartburn already common in pregnancy.If you've been having tummy trouble during your pregnancy, you're likely to have it while traveling, but you can take steps to lessen potential problems.Instead of eating three big meals, aim for several small meals throughout the day.Take your time eating and chew thoroughly. Don't gulp your drinks.Pack loose, comfortable clothing (nothing that's too tight around your waist or stomach).Advice for avoiding gas:Cut back on the foods that are most likely to cause gas. These include carbonated beverages, cabbage, cauliflower, brussels sprouts, broccoli, asparagus, leeks, onions, scallions, artichokes, dried fruit, pears, apples, honey, soda, fruit drinks, wheat, corn, potatoes, oat bran, beans, peas, and high-fat and fried foods.Advice for avoiding heartburn:Avoid foods and drinks that cause heartburn, such as alcohol (which you should avoid anyway during pregnancy); caffeine; chocolate; acidic foods like citrus fruits, tomatoes, mustard, and vinegar; processed meats; mint products; and spicy, highly seasoned, fried, or fatty foods.Don't eat dinner too close to your bedtime. Give yourself two to three hours to digest before lying down. And try sleeping with your upper body propped up with several pillows.Don't smoke  in addition to contributing to a host of serious health problems, smoking boosts stomach acidity. (Ideally, this is a habit you should break before getting pregnant. If you're still smoking and having trouble quitting, ask your caregiver for a referral to a smoking-cessation program.)An over-the-counter antacid that contains magnesium or calcium may ease discomfort, but check with your prenatal caregiver before taking one, because some brands are high in sodium.Pregnancy heartburn Play VideoPlayMuteCurrent Time 0:00/Duration Time 2:00Loaded: 0%0:00Progress: 0%0:00Progress: 0%Stream TypeLIVERemaining Time -2:00Playback Rate1ChaptersChaptersdescriptions off, selectedDescriptionssubtitles off, selectedSubtitlescaptions settings, opens captions settings dialogcaptions off, selectedCaptionsdefault, selectedAudio TrackFullscreenThis is a modal window.Caption Settings DialogBeginning of dialog window. Escape will cancel and close the window.TextColorWhiteBlackRedGreenBlueYellowMagentaCyanTransparencyOpaqueSemi-TransparentBackgroundColorBlackWhiteRedGreenBlueYellowMagentaCyanTransparencyOpaqueSemi-TransparentTransparentWindowColorBlackWhiteRedGreenBlueYellowMagentaCyanTransparencyTransparentSemi-TransparentOpaqueFont Size50%75%100%125%150%175%200%300%400%Text Edge StyleNoneRaisedDepressedUniformDropshadowFont FamilyProportional Sans-SerifMonospace Sans-SerifProportional SerifMonospace SerifCasualScriptSmall CapsDefaultsDonePlayMuteCurrent Time 0:00/Duration Time 0:00Loaded: 0%Progress: 0%Stream TypeLIVERemaining Time -0:00Playback Rate1ChaptersChaptersdescriptions off, selectedDescriptionssubtitles off, selectedSubtitlescaptions settings, opens captions settings dialogcaptions off, selectedCaptionsAudio TrackFullscreenClose Modal DialogThis is a modal window. This modal can be closed by pressing the Escape key or activating the close button.Many women experience heartburn during pregnancy. Learn why heartburn happens and how to find relief. See all pregnancy videos How can I relieve constipation?If you suffer from constipation before you go on a trip, traveling can make it worse. Sitting for long stretches, changing your diet and mealtimes, not having a restroom readily available when you need one, not drinking enough fluids  all these can wreak havoc on your bowels. Try these tips to relieve or avoid the problem:Bring high-fiber foods like bran cereal, whole-grain breads, fresh or dried fruit, and fresh vegetables to snack on.Drink plenty of water. Getting enough fluids helps keep your digestive system moving. Prune juice can be particularly helpful. The Institute of Medicine recommends that pregnant women have about 10 8-ounces cups of water or other beverages each day. (Drink more if it's warm out or you're exercising.) Another way to ensure proper hydration is to monitor your urine color  if it's dark yellow or cloudy, you need to drink more.Exercise. Take breaks to walk and stretch. At your destination, take advantage of hotel fitness centers and swimming pools or local facilities.Your bowels are most likely to be active after meals so try to leave time to use the bathroom after you eat and before you head out.Ask your healthcare provider about taking along an over-the-counter fiber supplement.Ask your provider if the iron in your prenatal vitamin could be the culprit. High doses of iron  more than 30 milligrams (mg)  can cause constipation or make it worse. As long as you're not anemic, you should be able to take a supplement that contains 30 mg or less of iron.Pregnancy constipation Play VideoPlayMuteCurrent Time 0:00/Duration Time 2:03Loaded: 0%0:00Progress: 0%0:00Progress: 0%Stream TypeLIVERemaining Time -2:03Playback Rate1ChaptersChaptersdescriptions off, selectedDescriptionssubtitles off, selectedSubtitlescaptions settings, opens captions settings dialogcaptions off, selectedCaptionsdefault, selectedAudio TrackFullscreenThis is a modal window.Caption Settings DialogBeginning of dialog window. This modal can be closed by pressing the Escape key or activating the close button.Constipation is common during pregnancy. What causes constipation, and how can you prevent it? See all pregnancy videosHow can I avoid fatigue?It's normal to tire more easily when you're pregnant. Your body is working overtime to support your growing baby. The demands of traveling  along with jet lag from time zone changes and other disruptions to your schedule  will only add to your fatigue.While you can still enjoy many of your favorite vacation activities, you may need to slow your usual pace, keep your schedule light, and give up the idea of seeing everything. Keep your plans as simple as possible, and think quality rather than quantity.Take naps. An afternoon snooze is an especially good way to avoid exhaustion. At your destination, set aside time each day to lie down, close your eyes, and drift off. Even if you can't take a full-fledged nap, pausing periodically during the day to put your feet up can help.Try to spend time outside in the daylight to help reset your biological clock to the new time zone.Keep evening meals light and non-greasy to help ward off the gastrointestinal discomforts that can keep you up at night. Cut back on caffeine and make sure you're drinking enough water to stay well hydrated. To head off middle-of-the-night trips to the bathroom, though, avoid drinking anything two hours before bedtime.Take a warm bath before bed to help you unwind and sleep more soundly.Go to bed as close to your normal bedtime as you can, unless you've crossed at least three time zones. In that case, it's best to try to adjust your sleep schedule to local time to combat jet lag.Lying on your side with a pillow between your knees is usually the most comfortable sleeping position for pregnant women. Keeping your upper body slightly elevated can help counteract heartburn, too.Show sources Hide sources ACG. Undated. Belching, bloating and flatulence.
